reviewText:
TL;DR: massively overhyped, it falls short of my expectations.

I pre-ordered this game because of the pre release information.
It is (afaik) the first Unreal Engine 4 game that's actually released and - if trailers are to be trusted - it seemed to use that engine quite well to create a believable nightmare.
This version however, seems to suffer from weak textures and visuals that would have been possible on the Unreal engine 3 as well.
Besides that, there are quite a lot of users right now suffering from crashes and instabilites in the Steam forums.
(and there is no way to change the game language completely - I am forced to use German text with spoken English, because the game simply won't become 100% English when set to that in Steam settings)

The game plays in a hospital / asylum / prison, which are all stuffed into the same building.
Your character starts off with a smartphone (doubling as a map and a torchlight) and has to gather so called relics.
Each relic is commented by some person with the comments being somewhere between annoying and a minor inconvenience - they just don't actually add to the gameplay or the atmosphere.

Then there is the actual game which has you run through corridors of ever-repeating models (the doors, the actual items placed around the rooms, ...) and visuals.
This game seems like a cheap modification for UT3, but neither the visuals nor any other aspect live up to my expectations of what the Unreal engine 4 would be capable of.

In that maze of repeating corridors there are random ghosts (which - you guessed it - seem like clones) spawning in on you.
While this might at first seem like a nice change of pace, simply because flickering lights and closing doors have been done before, it soon becomes exhausting.
You have got one and a half way of getting rid of ghosts.
The most effective one is to actually get rid of them by using a signalling torch similar to those used in road accidents (which you find on a regular basis in this madhouse...) - however, the next ghost might spawn in only a few seconds later.
Then there is the possibility of running away.
When actually choosing flight instead of fight, you will run in a ghost around the next corner, so it is not really an alternative in the long run.
(Besides, it's a maze that you are running through, with your path clearly laid out - so running away from the ghost actually forces you to retreat into the maze and hinders your progress, rendering it - all things considered - unfeasible)

The story seems somewhat normal.
There is this hospital in which patients die of mysterious" causes
recommended: ... - the usual stuff.\n\nAlthough I have not yet played through the whole game
hoursPlayed: I already regret pre ordering the game.\nThe gameplay has already overstayed its welcome
voteText: the visuals seem dated and the overall atmosphere just isn't as good as it seemed to be in the trailers.\nWhile I got it for almost 10$ it simply is not as satisfying as I am used to when comparing it to other games I got for this amount (and less)."

reviewText:
I started this game without knowing anything about it.
You randomly start in some abandoned building as a girl / woman with a smartphone through which some person talks to you.

You look around, find some notes, nothing too special.
There are blue notes and red notes. Once you pick up your first red note, a counter appears in the bottom right.
1 / 6 for instance. Seems a bit familiar.

There are two types of items you get walking around the halls: Glowsticks and Flares.

Glowsticks give a little bit more light and hint you at things you can actually interact with. Also they show your footsteps, helping you with orientation. This is quite important as the map on your smartphone is so tiny that you can hardly see stuff, even when zooming in (putting it closer to your face).

Flares have a defensive purpose. I'll explain later what that means.

So basically there is one simple and quite obvious pattern:
1. Get red notes
2. Find key to exit
3. Enter next area.

Now where is the scary part?
Besides some objects randomly moving when you pass them (of course only the first time to come along) and the actually quite good ambience, there is one threat so far: A ghost girl.

Is she scary? no... during the first chapter you see her already when she is like 100 meters away from you and you can casually walk away. When you look at her she attacks by standing still and screaming at you, which doesn't even have an effect, if you are far away. If this actually hits you, the screen starts turning black from outside to inside, making it extremely hard to see. Your visions gets better over time though. To avoid this, hold a flare in the ghost's face.

Once you reach the next chapter and it all starts again the ghost will actually appear directly behind you and there you have your slenderman clone.

Honestly, for anyone who has experience with horror, this game has nothing to offer except for startling you every now and then.
If you never touched a horror game before and want to start with something that isn't too horrible or if you plain and simple love to do the same thing over and over again, feel free to take a look at this.

Anybody who wants horror beyond cheap jumpscares and some actual gameplay should ignore this game.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=50uERCJtSiM&feature=youtu.be

With the rising popularity of YouTube let's plays and Twitch streaming, horror games have enjoyed a bit of a resurgence. This resurgence is, oddly enough, not due to people's desires to play these games themselves, but rather to watch others play them on the internet. I digress, whatever the reason, developers are back to delivering scars and suspense to those who have the steely nerves required to complete these games. Daylight attempts to elbow it's way to the front of the crowd, nudging past fan favorites like Slender: The Eight Pages, Outlast and Amnesia: The Dark Decent. With it's procedurally generated mazes and visuals bolstered by Epic's Unreal 4 engine, Daylight has the goods to garner the interest of fans but does it deliver the tension and scares of it's contemporaries?

Daylight wastes no time with any kind of lead-in or build up. Immediately, you take control of Sarah, a girl stranded in a dilapidated hospital who... Well, you aren't really told anything about Sarah...You don't see her face, aren't clued into her age or her background and why she's in the middle of this hospital is a mystery. The most intriguing aspect of Sarah is the bizzare maze-like network of lines that appear on her arm. With only her cell phone and a mysterious male voice to guide her, Sarah must wander around in search of documents called remnants and collecting all of the documents in an area allows her to obtain a sigil which unlocks a magically sealed door to the next area. If this sounds vaguely familiar, that's because it's pretty much the same set up as the Slender games. Along the way, pictures will fall off of walls unexpectedly, drawers from filing cabinets with shoot across the room and wheelchairs and IV drip racks will squeak across the floor in this veritable digital funhouse.

Nestled between each area that hosts a remnant hunt are areas that require some light puzzle solving and collecting more documents that attempt to build a narrative. The puzzles are inconsequential, requiring some switch flipping and crate pushing. Sarah can also use glowsticks to illuminate objects of interest since apparently the magical elements she encounters respond to chemiluminescence... Lockers, supply boxes and crates can all be opened for flares, glowsticks and documents. The problem is that all of this can be made frustrating as a result of clunky controls. Opening a locker can involve and awkward tango while trying to prompt the contextual command to pop up and grant Sarah access to it's contents. Pushable crates can only be moved from one side so players must circle them like a shark in order to find the side they can interact with. Sarah also moves at a ponderous pace by default meaning the patience of a zen master is required to navigate the environment. While she can sprint, the exaggerated head bob can make some players sick and is at the very least disorienting, making exploration difficult. The witches that want to tear Sarah limb from limb appear at random, often behind players and can be warded off with flares. Flares and glowsticks are not exactly in short supply but the real challenge is making it to the magically sealed doors with the sigil in hand since your trusty flares cannot be used. It can get frustrating when you find yourself cornered by a spawning witch with no recourse.

While players can get the same type of gameplay from several other games on the market, one would at least expect the narrative to differentiate Daylight from other titles. This would be a mistake however, since Daylight is on a strict diet of cliches and hackery. By dropping it's protagonist into a scenario without any introduction it drives a large wedge between players and the characters involved. Where the protagonists of other horror games reflect on their growing unease or decaying sanity, Sarah does nothing to reflect on her predicament aside from calling out into the dark, announcing that she is aware of some unseen presence. All of this culminates in an inane plot twist that has little consequence given the abysmal character development. There is nothing for players to be invested in and the mysteries surrounding the hospital, it's patients and Sarah merely come off as set dressing.

Given that Daylight is running on the shiny new Unreal 4 engine, one would at least expect it to look great but the procedural level generation betrays this expectation by requiring environments to be modular making it reminiscent of being trapped in one of Skyrim's dungeons. One room offers few details to distinguish itself from another and, were it not for the fact that there is an ever present map on Sarah's phone, getting lost would be a frequent occurrence. Props are generic and as a result many areas don't feel like they have a purpose and the decaying buildings that players have to navigate look sparse, with even simple details like windows being few and far between. Lighting is also rather generic as a result of this design so don't expect to see any of the extraordinary expressionist surroundings offered by a game like Outlast. Continuing the trend of treading well worn ground, Daylight also suffers from it's choice of environments by featuring horror game staples like a hospital, prison, sewers and a forest. Ultimately, Daylight lacks the all important atmosphere that allows a horror game to truly get under your skin in a way that jump scares cannot. Despite looking like a student project, the frame rate has a tendency to chug in some areas and I did experience a crash during my two hour playthrough. Sound design keeps the tension up but does little to stand out from similar games.

Daylight is truly embarrassing as it gormandizes on cliches and tropes, digests and squeezes them out of it's sphincter for Twitch streamers and let's play hosts to gobble up. There is absolutely no reason to endure Daylight, even with it's short play time. The decision to make Daylight a procedurally generated experience cuts it's nose off to spite it's face. Randomizing the design of levels does so much to negatively impact an already lackluster experience by stripping the atmosphere from the experience. The hubris required to commit such an atrocious design blunder in order to add replayability to a title that isn't even worth seeing through once is staggering. Everything you can find in Daylight is available in other, more enjoyable games. The uninspired gameplay and fan fiction grade narrative have no place in a world where titles like Amnesia and Outlast exist. If only this game never saw the light of day...

reviewText:
Understanding Daylight isn‚Äôt difficult. If you‚Äôre familiar with games like Slender or Amnesia you‚Äôll have a fair idea of what needs to be done.  Now not to take away anything from Daylight as it is in it‚Äôs own right a game separate from many others like it, I feel maybe I‚Äôve become a bit tired of the same ‚Äúspooky‚Äù tricks laid out in front of me.

Wheel chairs magically move. Drawers of desks slam open. Doors slowly creek open while the lights flicker from above. Wandering through what seems to be endless corridors, searching for remnants to proceed becomes tiresome even after thirty minutes.

The story plays out through text for a majority of the time. Giving you some insight to the horrific deeds that as plagued the hospital. Every once in awhile a man‚Äôs voice would chirp through your cell phone saying awkward things while Sarah annoying asks ‚Äúis someone there,‚Äù repeatedly.

Daylight was a short 1-2 hour trek through familiar territory.  The story, the setting, the environment, it feels like Deja Vu and it‚Äôs hard to wash those feelings away.

reviewText:
As a long term survival horror fan, I feel like the community is being way too harsh on this game, mostly due to completely wrong expectations.

If you are truly interested in Daylight, but the negative reviews keep you off, please read this to understand what exactly this game has to offer before expecting anything else from it.


Most survival horror games can be divided into two categories: puzzle-based action-adventures (early Resident Evil, Silent Hill, ObsCure) and the recent story-driven run and hide investigations (Penumbra, Amnesia, Outlast).

Which one is Daylight? Neither.

Remember Slenderman? The one that was in early beta but still got popular due to its basic yet effective gameplay formula? Since it became so popular, we had a huge number of clones, remakes and spiritual successors with different interpretations of the story and the monster himself. I don't know about you, but none of them were truly my cup of tea - not even the full Slender: The Arrival game itself.

Daylight is, though. It follows Slenderman's legacy every step of the way, while trading the open forest for procedurally generated corridors, which works for this type of gameplay. If you don't know what Slenderman is, here's a simple explanation of its mechanics: collect documents, avoid the enemy and never look at him. Looking at him triggers his aggro and scariness ensues. Very simple yet very effective.
Daylight uses the same mechanics with a few extra touches here and there which is enough to make the game stand out without overcomplicating it.

Its main issue is relying almost purely on cheap jumpscares, although even without them the atmosphere is quite unnerving. And as far as jumpscares go, Daylight can at the very least show some good ones. The ghost is well detailed, and the sound design is genuinely creepy. Bricks are expected to be ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

I understand why people dislike it. It's not as story-heavy as one would want, although IMO the ending was worth reading through the notes you find. Its scares are cheap and don't change throughout the game, the ghosts can be outsmarted and the overall experience leaves you wanting just a tad bit more... but if it's scares you want, then scares you shall get.

It's one of those games that you should force your friends to play and just enjoy them jumping out of their seats. Definitely far from a top-tier survival horror, but nowhere near as bad as people make it out to be. Know what the game offers and you shall be not disappointed with what it doesn't offer.

reviewText:
This game started off with a lot of potential and some really cool ideas. Randomizing the rooms every playthrough so its always different, allowing people who stream it to have their chat activate events, and some other cool little features. Sadly the rest of this game kinda flops and ruins the cool ideas behind this game. Lets start with the graphics and performance, they are both terrible. There is nothing special about this game, so I dont know why this game is so hard to run, even on a higher end PC. Then there is the story, or lack thereof, which hurts the game a lot because it starts off pretty good. However, I think the worst thing about this game is the enemy, the ghost lady who chases you around. She is completely useless. Why? Because she can only damage you when you are looking at her, so I ran through the game on hard without ever dying and barely taking damage.

Overall, this game had a lot of potential, but they dropped the ball on this one. Also feels like they put a lot more effort into aiming this game towards YouTubers instead of the average player, which I feel like is a pretty bad practice.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v_Kqwjtprn0

I was going to give a score of 5 out of 10 because yes, there have been improvements, but, the fact they are trying to prevent me from recording their game has now infact lowered the score from a 5 to a 2. (I did eventually work my way around their stupid little diagnostic tool)

Final review score for Daylight, due to shady practices in trying to stifle recorded video of this game, a 2 out of 10.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors


Move into a lovelier light
***I initially gave Daylight a non-recommendation at launch as it was a buggy, slow, ugly looking mess. Things have improved drastically over the course of the month and not only does the game enjoy stable frame-rates, I am able to push the graphics detail up without it causing my laptop to fizzle and burn***

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=265593908
Last year saw Outlast, another horror title set in a seemingly abandoned hospital/asylum hoarding dark secrets, bow to much success which in itself took many cues from Frictional Games much lauded Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Outlast added some interesting tweaks to the gameplay (such as the ability to vault over objects in ones way and be able to look behind you whilst running for your life from the terrors confined at Mount Massive, the asylum you sneak into to investigate). For the most part it worked and it worked really well. I enjoyed my time with it although I did feel it dropped the ball somewhere in the middle (a more refined cut would have gone a long way) and the sudden supernatural ending, whilst schlock-ly entertaining, was far from perfect.

Now cue music - we have another entry from Zombie Studios called Daylight. With its similar setting and trailers that ramp up the fear factor it would be churlish to pass this off as a simple Outlast clone as I initially did (apologies to the friend I disputed this over with). Having gone through the game a second time around I am starting to see that Daylight owes more to the Slenderman series of games than to Outlast or even Amnesia. Daylight cribs generously from Slenderman by having you basically run around the abandoned hospital gathering remnants (Daylights version of the Slenderman white pages) always keeping a close eye out for the spirits that haunt this ground. Daylight is procedurally generated horror title that just goes to prove that procedural and horror should NEVER, EVER be in the same sentence since each area you explore looks exactly like the previous area you just passed through. Plot is certainly not one of Daylights strong points and if former IGN journalist Jessica Chobot believes this is where her career should be headed then she is going to have to try a lot harder.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=256169540
The game plonks its main heroine, Sarah, in the above mentioned abandoned hospital and then proceeds to litter the place with glow-sticks. Why glow-sticks? You see glow-sticks help you solve clues but for all I knew and was told Sarah could have been on route to a rave and some kindly rave-type person had left some for other ravers to pick up on-route. So know that I know I am not actually going raving then why am I solving clues? Since exposition is so low on the ground as to be practically dead and buried the player isn't really told much to begin with. There is a clich√©d story of a hospital of horrors that surfaces through notes the player finds in the game world but its literally cut, copied and pasted from every other horror involving an abandoned hospital, a few dead witches and some possibly fruity doctors. These notes fill in the back-story but because this is a story we have all heard a hundred times before (think The Conjuring just set in an abandoned hospital), there really is no need to pay that close an attention. With a plot hacked straight from horror 101 what dialog Daylight does feature is ear-bleedingly awful.

Daylight does succeed on a few jump scares here and there but even those become so telegraphed (the map on the phone you carry will start to distort and you will hear the cackle of the dead witches). Copying the mechanics from Slenderman - these dead witches will oft pop out at you unexpectedly. I really was expecting a whole heap more from this title since the trailers actually made it out to be quite thrilling. The game is literally over within an hour and half and because it's procedurally generated your next adventure will still be the pretty much the same game you just spent 90 minutes wading through in the first place with just a few location swaps here or there.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=268605488
Daylight serves up every rusty horror clich√© in the book from moving cabinets to boxes being sprewn about as you approach and while I was hoping that Daylight was going to be the horror title for 2014; I have to say I left the game feeling somewhat ambivalent about it. Whilst I was not enjoying myself initially after launch (thanks to a host of game-crunching bugs) - giving the game a second go-around a month later was actually quite fun but still nothing remarkable. Thank the horror-stars that the DLC for Outlast has arrived to scare the crap out of horror game aficionados as Daylight's bark is definitely far worse than its bite. In fact it turns into a bit of a whimper as the game winds down to its conclusion.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
From the get-go we are tossed onto our asses into an asylum with only a cell phone and a cheap Malcolm McDowell imitator barking nonsense over the speaker. He just spouts out grade-school philosophy such as ‚ÄúLife is but a butterfly‚Äôs dream,‚Äù and ‚ÄúHell hath no fury like a woman scorned‚Ä¶ and you‚Äôve scorned them all.‚Äù With @John_Henry_Eden_ebooks as our good company, we stumble around in the dark hallways (using useless glowsticks and flares) of which you will see the same of many times. One of Daylight‚Äôs big selling points is that it is randomly generated as you play so you can never have the same play experience twice. Well that doesn‚Äôt help when every single room is the same non-memorable one over and over again, does it?

The goal of every area you visit is to collect 6 ‚Äúremnants‚Äù, which is an absurdly vague way of saying ‚ÄúFind 6 pieces of paper with a red rune on them, some of which will be hidden in boxes on the walls and in desks‚Äù. Once you‚Äôve stuffed enough Macguffins into your jacket, Ol‚Äô Phoney pipes up mentioning that the ‚ÄúSigil‚Äù has been revealed. While that sounds like something deep and meaningful, all it really turns out to be is a pair of surgical scissors or a porcelain doll floating in a room covered in glowing writing that you most likely already found before you had all six remnants. In taking the Sigil, you become defenseless as you are no longer able to whip out any flares or glowsticks to protect yourself.

‚Ä¶oh, right. I forgot something. The ghost. From the outset you‚Äôre being pursued by an apparition that appears out of the blue with little rhyme or reason. My first encounter with it was as follows: I heard a banshee cry out from behind me as I was in mid-turn. My cell phone minimap was beginning to distort with random artifacts and glyphs. I stopped moving and waited for a moment, noticing that I could see what appeared to be the leg of the creature standing there just to my right. I contemplated for a moment what may happen should I continue to turn. All the while it persisted on making weird hissy noises. And then, almost as quickly as it came, the creature disappeared. It felt like one of those hilariously bad special effects sequences in old low budget films where they paused recording while the person or object was moved off camera while everyone else held still before continuing to record to give the illusion that they had vanished in an instant.

You see, Daylight has a lot of problems. It fails to be truly engaging to the player at any point. All plot exposition is taken care of via the notes and remnants (there are two colors of seal on the paper to designate the difference!) which you can skip most of and most likely will because it is all drivel. Any tension is completely ruined by the fact that none of the game‚Äôs systems work to support each other. Sarah can sprint indefinitely, which makes the ghost a trivial occurrence in the event that it manages to even spawn. Resource management is merely an afterthought thanks to being given free flares and glowsticks in almost every other room. And if you manage to fill up too much on either, finding one in a container causes you to just completely discard it. I‚Äôm pretty sure no human alive is going to just throw out a precious glowstick before finding at least one extra pocket to cram it into.

The game does not look nearly as demanding as it claims to be and none of the setpieces are visually interesting or even memorable. Between the campy dialog, shoddy notes and head-shake inducing comments in the UI message area claiming ‚ÄúThey will come to haunt you‚Äù, every bit of the writing is downright amateurish and is something to be ashamed of. The in-game Twitch streaming support tells me more about what was on the developers‚Äô minds than anything else in the game. They were banking on the braindead simple stream avenue to perpetuate the game with its enticing look and promise of replayability via randomization.

What they forgot to do was make a game worth playing, watching or thinking about.

reviewText:
It is Slender.  You trudge through some corridors, find sheets of paper and walk away from a ghost lady.  Sometimes you get to watch canned animations when climbing over objects, and very rarely you pull a switch or two to open up a new part of the level.

The default field of view is atrocious, and there is no menu to change the control scheme, although the FOV can be changed in configuration files, and likely so can the controls.  The lack of accessible menus for these things, however, shows such immense negligence on the part of the developers.

There's some controversy over getting that Jessica Chobot fellow to write the story for the game.  Except she didn't really write it.  There are a bunch of tiny blurbs scattered everywhere on small sheets of paper that are undoubtedly as original as tiny blurbs can get, but the dialogue can't possibly be attributed to an actual author.  Every single line of dialogue is a platitude that the writer got from somewhere else and thought sounded cool.

Being a graphical apologist on many levels, I understand that the visuals are fine to look at, but it's rather humorous that this is the first Unreal Engine 4 game to be released.  It looks overall like something you'd find released early in the last console generation, with lots of shortcuts taken, like stacks of books being little more than blurrily textured rectangular prisms, or wood grain textures with the sharpness of cheap plastic.  Little bits like the cloth physics and lighting are much more contemporary, but they don't warrant such steep system requirements, especially since most of the game is set in very tiny corridors.  It's all the baggage of a cutting edge game engine without any of the cutting edge.

What a wonderful time to be alive.

reviewText:
Procedurally generated hallways, slender style note gathering objectives. I don't necessarily 100% recommend this game, but I am not willing to give it a negative review, as what it did propose to offer, it lived up to well.

Running with the key is a tense moment, with the encroaching darkness. Thought there would have been a bit more of a dynamic layout, rather than just hallways, but that was my impression, not really what the devs promised.

Was mostly hoping there would have been a little more development post-release.

Competent gameplay nonetheless
voteText: 34 of 49 people (69%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You start in some type of ward, with someone directing you via your phone to pick up some glowsticks and start exploring. You pickup on the events of this place through notes scattered throughout the map. This causes constant pauses to read notes, which I stopped doing halfway through, merely picking them up to access the key to progress through the next door. I found they ruined the flow of the game, and didn't offer much info except paranormal activity and the actions of crazed inmates. Nothing you can't imagine on your own.

The glowstick/flare mechanics are interesting though, yet somewhat broken. It seemed like some cabinets/desks were only discoverable while lighting a glowstick, but on the neat side, they showed your footsteps. That helped you run through the game faster without having to bother with the phone map, as you could tell where you had been.

The flare wards off the nurse ghost, who will get close to you in most areas because of the tight mapping. She becomes more determined as you advance through each section. You can't use a flare while holding the key object though, so you're forced to make a vulnerable dash to the door. Take that as you will. At one point I was on a dock but I couldn't pick up flares from a box on a wooden post because I apparently couldn't see them, until I lit one. *SPOILER* I then blew a large gas tank to advance, meanwhile I could have just jumped over the damn boxes.

The areas of this game are formulaic, with repeating assets in each. I had one or two jump scares when the nurse pops up infront of me. I had my settings on medium and it ran mediocre. The key bindings are not changeable, and the FOV is narrow. I tried editing the ini files but it didn't end up working, and carried on with the game.

Ending was terrible.

I'm a fan of survival/horror/adventure but I'd suggest skipping this one. Wait for Routine or something.

4/10

reviewText: Daylight is a first-person randomly generated survival-horror game. Or how I like to call it, 'Pseudo Pac-Man'.\n\nBasically, this is the game; You got a story area where you're safe, and story things happen, then you get thrown into a randomly generated maze, where you have to find a key, and find the exit. And then rinse and repeat, over and over, until the game is done. They try and throw a few things in to make it more 'interesting', with random scares in mazes and 'puzzles' in the safe areas. But the scares are super weak for the most part, and the 'puzzles' are such riveting things such as, Push this glowing crate in front of this higher stack of glowing crates
date: or, Find the switch to open up this secret door." Riveting.\n\nNow
recommended: I may have drawn attention to my Pac-Man example
hoursPlayed: let me explain... Since most of the horror is a maze
voteText: you sort of just waka-waka your way through these mazes
helpfulPercent: which get larger as the game goes on. You have a map that forms on the phone you always carry in-front of your face as you explore
votesHelpful: and as you go there are 'consumable' story pages that you can pick-up (no worries
votesFunny: yo~). And as you explore
commentsCount: there is a ghost that goes after you. And you look for flares

column17: though. Essentially the ghost approaches you
column18: and when it gets too close and you look at it
column19: you lose. Ghost can teleport around like Slender
column20: and sometimes you'll turn around and it'll be right there and you die. Also
column22: which you use to make objects you can interact with highlightable.\n\nIt's all fun enough
column23: but hardly scary to me. I was not scared once when playing the game
column24: though was tensed-up during a few closer encounters. It doesn't help that the two main characters (the one who you play as and some guy talking to you on the phone) are very unlikable. You see a chair slightly move. "Ohhhhhhhhh
column25: your character says all scared-like. A tile falls from the ceiling. Ohhhhhhhh." You start to realize that the character's reacting to try and be 'in-touch' with the player
column26: but it isn't working. She cries to herself that she's scared. She says lines like
column27: "What was that? Was there something behind me?
column28:
when clearing there isn't. And says she hears noises when there's no audio at all and stupidly calls out at random if anyone's there, and just... Ugh... I haven't felt this dissonant from a horror protagonist in a long time.

And then there's Mr. Guy on the Radio, who was never explained who exactly he was, but you can take some guesses. He's a guy on a radio, who's official occupation seems to be saying cryptic ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that means absolutely nothing. He'll ring off every once in a while, mostly when you pick up stuff, and rant on like some living Fortune Cookie.

And the story is incredibly disappointing, the files are lackluster to decent, and the ending is all kinds of disappointing. I'd tell you the story, but honestly there's hardly any story to tell. I guessed the stories big plot twist literally in the first five minutes of the game. And the story hardly has any presence in the game anyways.

The randomly generated aspect doesn't feel too needed, as most of the rooms look similar for the most part, and can either make what you're objective is stupidly easy, or a lot harder than it needs to be. I think randomly generated mazes wasn't the best idea on the devs, the game is pretty linear so the random level layout often can make the levels themselves feel rather poor more often than not. Scares and all that I can understand being randomized, but in a game that's at heart a linear corridor horror game, the random feature literally in this case just shifts halls and rooms around.

But it's decent fun, and it looks fairly pretty. The music is nice. I'd say it's decent if it's cheap, but it's honestly a very mediocre game. It's not terrible or even bad I'd say, I'd just say it falls short.of its promise, and it almost all comes from poor choices. The mechanics are good, and there's groundwork here for a good horror game, but the execution just falls flat a lot of the time.

Buy if cheap and like horror games as it's not terrible, but not worth it full price either, and honestly rather average as a whole.And it feels like a lot of other games that have come out in the last few years.

reviewText:
Just don't buy it There are plenty of survival horror games that are much better. This game is broken in so many ways, just look at the forums tons of users who can't even play. I am able to run it for what that's worth, but the controller support is still lacking. Also the devs really (from what I have seen others might have a different response) don't seem to think they need to fix anything. I have seen post by devs where they basically blamed the users (not flat out implied) for buying a game their system can't run. But that's the thing a lot of these systems should be able to run it and it just doesn't work. If you have a really good DX11 computer and feel like rolling the dice be my guest, but I say wait and see if the devs actually release any updates. Hasn't been one for at least a few months and the game only came out in April I think there was one in May.

Update:

It really falls short on gameplay there are many other survival horror games that do a much better job at suspense.
It has an orginal idea, but it's not enough to break off from games like Slender, Amnesia, and Outlast. A lot of the scary stuff has literally been used in these other games and the effect is just getting tiresome.

There are lots of complaints from users about lag. Threads with hundreds of posts, and then you have to listen to people tell you that your computer is not really DX11 and you don't really know what you are doing.

Even if you getting running without lag chances are you are not going to play it that much, after all it is just walking down halls the whole time.

Just take a look at the other reviews and some posts on the forums chances are you will turn away and run screaming from this game.

reviewText:
Daylight is a first-person survival horror game.
The player awakens as a young woman trapped inside an abandoned hospital with a smartphone conveniently at her side. A creepy man barks instructions and vague allusions to her past through the phone, which also acts as a map and a light. Glow sticks can be collected and used for light and double as a basic hint system, casting a soft green glow to highlight item containers or puzzle mechanisms. Flares are the only other usable items and are used to fend off the creepy witch ghost thing that haunts you throughout the game.
You know how most horror games like to embellish their worlds with various collectable files or documents that help to fill in the backstory of what is really going on. In Daylight, collecting these documents is the primary mechanic of gameplay. The basic structure of each level goes as follows: find at least five or six of these documents called ‚Äúremnants‚Äù (they are usually briefs notes or the occasional photo), bring the remnants to a designated symbol to acquire a special artifact called a Sigil and then use the Sigil to open a magic barrier and continue on your way. Repeat, again and again and this is the whole game.
If this sounds boring, it‚Äôs because it is. Think the main hook from Slender, but stretched out over 60 to 90 minutes.
The replay value of Daylight is almost nonexistent, even when taking into account its procedurally generated nature. The thing is, the game itself is so lifeless and devoid of any actual gameplay, that it‚Äôs incredibly hard to justify experiencing the adventure for a second time at all.
Daylight is the retail debut of Unreal Engine 4 but the graphics look shockingly outdated.
The sound effects do not help matters all that much, either. You will have the expected banging on doors and low howls in the distance, but it is Sarah‚Äôs own commentary that ends up being the biggest thing at fault here. Sarah has about three or four different dialogue options that she cycles through densely and incessantly, with weird choices of pausing by the actor like ‚ÄúIs anyone‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶there?‚Äù and ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt see anything!‚Äù and ‚ÄúI know someone‚Äôs there!‚Äù
In terms of both a game‚Äôs atmospheric scare factor and enjoyable gameplay, Daylight is essentially a poor man‚Äôs Amnesia, and does not even come close to the current king of the genre, Outlast.

Sounds 4/10
Graphics 4/10
Gameplay 3/10
Atmosphere 3/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
I know there seems to be a common sentiment that this game completely sucks, but I have to say I very much enjoyed it.

So here's the thing:
Are you the type of person who likes to turn the lights out at night, put your headset on, and prepare yourself to be scared out of your pants?
Are you the type of person that likes to look for clues and enjoys piecing them together to figure out a story?

If you do, this game is for you.
If you don't, this game is not for you. Don't play it.

Yeah the graphics aren't anywhere near great. No, you can't bind controls, you're stuck with what the game gives you. Yes, the game is somewhat short and repetitive, though because it's short, it obviously can't be too repetitive, right? There are four levels, and you play them the exactly same way: hence repetitive. Yes, each level is a maze, so you must like mazes.

Honestly, there are things about this game that could have and should have been done better, but as far as in game experience and story go, I give the game an A.

reviewText: If this game didn‚Äôt come free with my GTX 770, I never would have bought it.  It was not very fun and gets old quick walking around looking for things. reviewText:
I <3 this game! Started playing it tonight and the ambience helps create a terrifying game. The dark halls, the bangs, the  FREAKING SCARY SHADOW PEOPLE EEEEEEEEEK scared the pants off me. I shrieked with every sound. The graphics are pretty darn good, the soundtrack by Alex Guilbert and Ivory Gray-Smith is fantastic - only 3 songs but 3 brilliant atmospheric creepy songs. Only issue I had was I was playing it with a replica xbox controller and it made turning a little hard and very slow so I died twice while trying to run away as I had no flares to scare off those SCARY shadow people :'( so I will try it next time with just keyboard & mouse.

I definitely recommend it if you want to get your heart racing and a sore voice from screaming.
Or maybe that just happens to me hehehehe :)

reviewText: Nothing but endless doors and corridors, with you trying to find randomly scattered notes so you can collect the piece of cursed garbage and escape to the next area to do it again. Game only manages to  provide decent chills through the environment, but they quickly lose their charm after seeing room 5 and corridor 2 for the fifth time. The main antagonist is more of a haunted house spook than an actual threat, and the minor scripted events are laughable(floating spooky skull is my favorite). Also since everything looks the same, it makes finding the notes you're missing tedious and boring, and the useless map doesn't help, since it doesn't differentiate between dead ends and unopened doors. The box shoving reminds of a PS1 game, and serves only to break up the 100 meter dash that is the main portion of the content. Save your money and your time, don't even get on a steam sale.

reviewText:
I REALLY wanted to like Daylight. I really did. It had alot of cool things going for it, like randomly generated levels, showing off the 4th version of the Unreal Engine, and Actually being a horror game with ghosts in it (count the amount of horror games with ghosts in them. I can only count them on one hand.) but it turned out to be another disappointment. Why??? Well, ill attempt to explain why.


THE GOOD
One of the good things going for Daylight is the lighting. Daylight has some great lighting, and it shows it off with the use of the different items in the game like the flares.  Another cool thing is most of the environments. From a sewer, to the outside, alot of the areas look pretty good and creepy. The only areas that aren't very good are the first two but besides that, they are very well made environments. One last thing is the sound. Not all of the sound is good and the way most of the sound is used is rather crappy, but many other SFXs are great, and are fitting with the setting. The sound that tells you a ghost is nearby and most of the old, worn out doors are very creepy, and set the mood perfectly.


Also, the way Twitch (Livestreaming) is integrated is neat as well.



THE BAD
Here's where it all goes downhill. one thing to make your game scary is be crafty and paced well. Daylight fails at this. Here are daylights regular" scares.

- cheap jumps scares

-doors opening by themselves (SPOOOOOKY)

-Objects getting flung around

-and loud screams that get old about the third time they are used

Sure
date: most people will find this scary
recommended: but I don't. Jump scares can be scary if done right
hoursPlayed: but ones that are thrown out of nowhere with no buildup are not scary. Daylight does that so many times its not even funny. As for doors and objects magicly opening or get thrown
voteText: its such a done to death cliche I roll my eyes instead of being scared. And the loud screams are pretty self explanatory. The worst part is the gameplay. Here is the entirety of daylights gameplay. 1. Enter level. 2.collect 6 pages. 3.go to the key. 4. Go to exit. 5.rinse and repeat. Sound familiar
votesHelpful: this is pretty much a rip-off of the smash hit horror game
votesTotal: Slender: The Eight Pages (which I don't like either). Not only that
votesFunny: but it gets extremely repetitive later in the game. Another thing that is bad is the lack of enemy variety. The entire game
commentsCount: you're being chased by ONE ghost the whole game
column16: and its design is very bland. Because of this
column17: it adds on to the repetition and bore-factor of the game. One last thing is the story and characters. The story is told through notes and slight (and I mean slight) exposition between levels. I would have been fine with this if not for the fact that it is very bland and uninteresting from start to finish. Most of the notes are either ZOMG I SAW SOMEONE RUN AROUND WHERE I WAS AND IVE NEVER SEEN HIM IN MY LIFE! To ZOMG SOMEONE DIED! It got to the point where reading them felt like a chore. Another thing is that the protagonist is SOOO annoying. I give props for not using the "silent character" approach
column18:
but id rather prefer that then this. The entire game Sarah will say "Is anyone there" to "What was that?" And it gets annoying real fast because of how many voice clips are used over and over again.

THE VERDICT
What a disappointment. It had alot of potential
column19:
but wound up being boring and uninspired. 3/10.

reviewText:
I played this game with two other people, and if your not used to horror games you will get scared, even the slightest movement will make you jump. I had fun watching my friend play and had some fun playing it as well. I got this game for free so I don't really have anything to complain about.

I don't really like the story how it makes no sence and you are pretty much thrown into the game. That is the only flaw. I have also read this is a copy of some othere game, but if I didn't know this I would of thought that game was a copy of this. I'm not big on horror games so for a first one I will say go ahead and get it, it's your choice after all.

TL;DR - Good game for some scares, I got for free so don't any better. Buy or don't your choice.

reviewText:
7.5/10   (8.5/10 if they patch the technical problems)

+ use of unreal  engine 4 for the first time, not that impressive (in this game), but it shows that it can produce some very nice special effects and great lighting.
+ creepy atmosphere, good horror story told by reading scattered notes and seeing some cursed pictures and by listening to the ... narrator, very nice sound (maybe the best part of the game) and atmospheric soundrack
+ gameplay wise it's divided into maze like areas where you have to find clues (those are the notes you read and pictures) using green sticks that help you identify them ,while at the same time trying to avoid the ghost girl (you will find out what that really is in the end) by running or using red sticks - it's much more gameplay wise than slender, since there is a nice story to back all this gameplay up and the whole design is much better here
+ really liked the last areas which were more open , more good-looking and the story started to unfold

- technical issues - mainly poor performance and many crashes (had to restart the game many times during the  last stage)
- short game, took me less than 5 hours and i was trying to read and comprehend everything , also lost some time trying to configure it to run properly on my system
- no replayability even if they claim that it is different every time you start a new game, didn't try it a second time, but these games are about the story which you get to know by finishing it once
- although developers wanted to make a game with a simple gameplay like that, still they could at least use some puzzles or more gameplay elements (for sure not fighting) to make it more interesting

in conclusion, i enjoyed the game, maybe due to the fact that i didn't expect the next silent hill game, instead i played it for what it was and i recommend it.

reviewText: Such wasted potential.  I came into this game hoping to experience a truly horrifying game with levels that are never the same twice.  What I got instead was a extremely formulaic find-the-hidden-object Slender clone Piewdiebait with levels that all look the same; making it very easy to get lost and a lot of boring cheap scare attempts that are so cliche and poorly executed I would have thought that this game was supposed to be FUNNY.  The entire first level and most of the second level are completely void of any danger and just try to creep you out with such scary tactics as a chair sitting up by itself or drawers flying open or a wheelchair wheel spinning by itself.  The only times when I was GENUINELY scared were the times when you're not allowed to carry a protective flare and you have to take the Macguffin back to the gate while being chased by a ghost; and those moments were only scary because it's easy to get lost in the samey-looking levels and the spooky" ghosts making a loud noise whenever you look at them.  And the thing is that because of the formula (find six letters that let you unlock the Macguffin that opens the next level and run away from ghost) these moments don't stay scary for long as you know EXACTLY what to expect by the third time around.  And it's a shame because the game actually has a quite nice athmosphere with dark
date: claustrophobic hallways of a rundown insane asylum and a dark forest.  But these are the ONLY two sections of the game and by the time that you're done with these sections
recommended: then the game is over.  However
hoursPlayed: as the game is only 2-3 hours long
voteText: this might not be a bad thing."

reviewText: Wont even work, I have talked with people since release still wont work and many people cannot get it to work , or have problems with it playing. I have everything up to date everything I need the devs told me that I had everything good, and also I passed the diag test tool they give you (since there was such a problem they needed one) I honistly rarely post bad reviews or feel I should get my money back, this is the first time I feel completely screwed. For running the new UR4 engine from what I am seeing is not very amazing. And the patches they do roll out seem to break things even more or fix one thing break another.\nThis upsets me, being said that I talked to the people who made it and it still failing to change anything and doing all I can to fix it. I wasted my time, and I am not sure it was worth my time to fix from what others are saying. Many people say it runs really really hot on high end rigs even for how bad it looks. This is a Alpha it seems, for being delayed it is not at all finished, I mean even at release the first patch was 1.0 so I do think it was sent out from beta. Yet still doesn't work, heck even with EA I don't have this many problems, and at least they are fixed and not telling you to do the same 3 things 100 times and jump through 200 hoops to play a 2 hour long game about. Please intill this is all fixed if it ever is save your money, it isn't worth it go buy slender for 2 bucks on sale or something or dread out, I was so hoping for this but just feel robbed , I even pre ordered because it looked so cool.

reviewText:
This is the first indie survival horror game that I have ever beaten start to finish. Let that sink in... Having played a bit of amnesia, a few the fps/tps horror games and that jazz, this falls short in comparison to it when it comes to writting. As a lot of the dialog doesn't make sense or is misused in certain areas as the player will use the same phrases over an over at random points.

Gameplay wise, it's not so bad the core concept of this game actually reminded me of slender combined with the randomly generate worlds which made the first 2 diablos fun mixed in with a few jump scares. Which by the way get pretty predictable but still can catch you off guard from time to time.

So over all I probably can recommend this game with the disclamer those who are new to the genre such as myself or casual horror genre players who are looking to only get their feet wet. Those of you who are die hard fans, you probably wanted to play slender to begin with if you want to play this game.

reviewText:
It's a good game for the price but MASSIVE OVERHYPE done by YouTube Let's players....

Bad points:
*Micro stuttering - specially when turning around
*No matter what graphics card and CPU you have,FPS is not going to reach any higher than 40-50 at any resoultion at any settings
*Some bugs
*When I play this game,6-7 of my 8 GB ram is used
*Fully eats video card memory
*CPU hog (my FX-6300 runs at 70% with it while GTA IV takes only 40-50%)
*Bad/blurry graphics compared to nowadays
*Too many glowsticks/flares that make the Witch√üitch go away...
*No ablity to jump,only climb boxes with the same animation of a climbing left hand and a right leg
*You usually can hear the Witch behind you,so there is no jumpscare when you turn around because you know what's gonna happen
*Every corridor basically looks the same and as the game map is randomly generated,many places repeats (once happened to me,entering a room opening the door entering an other and than an other room that was exactly the same as the first hall/reception like room in the hospital)

Good points:
*Now I feel like they kinda patched the difficulity,there are more jumpscares than I beated it first
*Easier to die
*Creepy athmosphere and graphics
*Some good camera shaking effect
*Sometimes does some good jumpscares
*The game is not too expensive/reasonibly priced
*Good to play at night,alone :)


Additional notes:
Many player did not manage to start-up the game
Does not support almost any video capture software (like FRAPS or Bandicam)
DX 11.1 compatible graphics card needed
Not for low-end PCs
Do not bother buying it unless you have got at least as powerful graphic card as HD7850-HD7870 or the R9 270X / GTX 660Ti

Randomly generated map supposed to offer infite replayibility but after a time,you get bored at the jumpscares that are almost all the same and saying *whatever* after each one.

reviewText:
Daylight: probably one of the strangest names that Zombie Studios could have given it, as there is an immediate scarcity of the stuff. ‚ÄòNighttime‚Äô probably would have been a more fitting title for the game, as it‚Äôs clich√©, much like the rest of the game itself.

Daylight is a survival horror game in which each area is randomly generated upon entering it, thus allowing a different game each time you play through it. Being the first game ever to use the Unreal Engine 4, it has a lot to live up to in order to make it a game to remember.

As you start, you wake on the floor with no memory of who you are or how you got there. All you have is a phone, which acts as a flashlight, a map and a means of communications for a mysterious voice that guides (or attempts to) you through the game, but rarely actually helps. Instead, the voice either confuses you with riddles or mocks you in some way. After investigating the room, you open a door and discover you‚Äôre in an asylum. You progress past each level by collecting remnants (pieces of paper that contain information of the asylum‚Äôs past.) Once you‚Äôve collected enough remnants, a key appears, which is an object that one of the former inmates were very fond of, like a doll or The Bible. This is used to unlock the doorway and progress to the next level. Not all remnants appear during one playthrough, meaning people who like to 100% games will find joy in playing through it multiple times.

Through the areas you can find glow sticks and flares. Glow sticks cause objects of interest to glow, whether it is because they can be searched or moved, making them an invaluable tool which you will find yourself using a lot throughout Daylight.

As you collect more remnants, your threat level gets higher, causing the Witch to appear. There is little to no explanation about why the Witch is there or how she got there. The higher the threat level is, the more persistent she is at attacking and following you. Unfortunately, she is too easy to evade. Lighting flares keeps her away for the duration of the flare‚Äôs light, but merely running in the opposite direction or even running straight past her also suffices, as once you have seen her, she seems to forget the aspect of using her legs, meaning she just stands there gormless until you look away.

I‚Äôm not going to lie though, the moments when she does appear are terrifying, especially when she is dangerously close to you when you see her. The moments when she does appear are pulled off just right, the obvious things such as how the camera pans round to her automatically when she‚Äôs a set distance to you, the sudden music, the scream she lets out to the way she immediately lurches forward slightly once you see her, as if she‚Äôs going to jump through your screen and slap you across the face as you scream like a little ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

If this is sounding scarily (no pun intended) similar to Slender, that‚Äôs because it is. Running around in circles, hearing loud noises until you find all the pages gives a strange sense of d√©j√† vu. Like Slender, the most annoying part of the game is when you have all but one remnant (or page, in Slender‚Äôs case) and you‚Äôre running in circles trying to find the damn thing whilst desperately avoiding whatever it is that is practically hanging off your buttcheeks.

Each level is a different part of the asylum, starting with the hospital, then the prison, then the sewers and finally ending with the forest. These (theoretically) should get harder as they go on, but it goes the opposite way. For me, the hospital was the largest area and was made a lot more like a maze, even to the point of having multiple floors. The game actually gets easier after that. The prison is a rather small area, as are the sewers. The forest is literally that; a big open forest area, meaning getting away is easy, especially as there isn‚Äôt any stamina to limit your running, allowing you to just sprint around until you find an area of interest. I understand that they are randomly generated, but so are the levels in The Binding of Isaac, and they get larger and more difficult the deeper you get, so why can't it be the same here?

The game itself took me two and a half hours to complete, and about half of that was spent looking for the last remnant in each area whilst avoiding Witch attacks every ten seconds. Point is, if you‚Äôre looking for a long game, Daylight is the wrong place to be looking.

As I mentioned before, Daylight is the first game to use the Unreal Engine 4, and it has put it to very good use. The environments and game itself is beautiful to look at (except the screaming ladies) and very clearly boasts the power of UE4. Even to things such as how dynamic the lighting is. For instance, at one point I was standing behind a table, trying to regain my composure not long after a Witch attack. As I was standing still, my character started waving the glow stick in her hand around, and as she did, the shadow of the table I was behind moved accordingly to how she moved the glow stick. Just small things like that show the potential of what Unreal Engine 4 can do and really add to the experience.

Overall, Daylight is a game that had the potential to overthrow games like Outlast and Amnesia. Armed with randomly-generated areas and Unreal Engine 4, it should have, but boring and repetitive gameplay, clich√© design, small length and general unoriginality unfortunately let it down massively.



4.5/10

Pro‚Äôs
Looks brilliant
Best scares I‚Äôve seen in a long time
Multiple playthroughs appeal to hoarders

Con‚Äôs
Too unoriginal
Way too short
Littered with horror-clich√©‚Äôs
Got easier the further I got
Get‚Äôs boring after a while

reviewText:
It's a good game for the price but MASSIVE OVERHYPE done by YouTube Let's players....

Bad points:
*Micro stuttering - specially when turning around
*No matter what graphics card and CPU you have,FPS is not going to reach any higher than 40-50 at any resoultion at any settings
*Some bugs
*When I play this game,6-7 of my 8 GB ram is used
*Fully eats video card memory
*CPU hog (my FX-6300 runs at 70% with it while GTA IV takes only 40-50%)
*Bad/blurry graphics compared to nowadays
*Too many glowsticks/flares that make the Witch√üitch go away...
*No ablity to jump,only climb boxes with the same animation of a climbing left hand and a right leg
*You usually can hear the Witch behind you,so there is no jumpscare when you turn around because you know what's gonna happen
*Every corridor basically looks the same and as the game map is randomly generated,many places repeats (once happened to me,entering a room opening the door entering an other and than an other room that was exactly the same as the first hall/reception like room in the hospital)

Good points:
*Now I feel like they kinda patched the difficulity,there are more jumpscares than I beated it first
*Easier to die
*Creepy athmosphere and graphics
*Some good camera shaking effect
*Sometimes does some good jumpscares
*The game is not too expensive/reasonibly priced
*Good to play at night,alone :)


Additional notes:
Many player did not manage to start-up the game
Does not support almost any video capture software (like FRAPS or Bandicam)
DX 11.1 compatible graphics card needed
Not for low-end PCs
Do not bother buying it unless you have got at least as powerful graphic card as HD7850-HD7870 or the R9 270X / GTX 660Ti

Randomly generated map supposed to offer infite replayibility but after a time,you get bored at the jumpscares that are almost all the same and saying *whatever* after each one.

reviewText:
This is literally Slender: the 8 pages.
After reaching each new HUB area you are tasked to finding 6 'pages', with each one filling up your on-screen 'Threat' metre. The higher this metre is, the more chance Slender - er, I mean some random ghost/witch thing has of spawning and chasing after you. Sound Familiar?
It just seems to follow the same formula over and over again. Interesting puzzles/change of pace in gameplay as we've seen in Amnesia or Outlast this is not, sadly. =(

The selling point of 'procedurally generated' maps sounds awesome at first too until you literally stumble across the second or third identical looking room in a row over a 10 minute period.

The protagonist's VA work of gasps and screams leave alot to be desired, much of the time these come across as eye rollingly cringeworthy, and other times humorous even.

For one of the first Unreal 4 engine games it certainly doesn't look much impressive either, I actually had to go and google to make sure that this was indeed the one I had heard about using the new engine because of how mediocre and not-at-all special it looked/played. This is one of those game Devs that can't seem to comprehend or understand the problem with FOV's either, the default value being something reminiscent of The Darkness II's motion sickness and nausea inducing narrow as hell fiasco. Thankfully (via the community's involvement and not at all by the dev themself...) there's editable .ini files to bring this up to basic PC playable standard, still it just baffles me that in this day and age how this can continually be a problem with each new first person game release... is it ignorance or laziness?

At the end of the day I personally can't complain at the $5 deal I got this through via Hookups, and I guess alot of the hate stems from the hype of the new engine whereas the game in question is actually pretty average, but.. yeah I would recommend to wait for a sale at the very least.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rtA-Ee4lsSY&index=8

Daylight is a survival horror video game released on 29th April for PC and PS4. It‚Äôs being developed by Zombie Studios and it‚Äôs first game which is using Unreal Engine 4.

Despite many previous horror games which are similiar size, Daylight have to provide a lot more. Beside really creepy and scary atmosphere 99% of the time player will not be able to escape their destiny, to be scared !

You are in control of character who have aweoken in a random abandoned hospital. You have no idea why are you either your female character in that hospital but only way to find out whats happening is to seek notes, documents and possessed messages that find their way to your cell phone. Only navigation and constant light is your cell phone which will be shaking around while you are running so no matter how much you are scared you will need to find safe corners and observe explored map and potential ways to go further deep into level.

You arent going to have access to any weapons but whatsoever you will have glow sticks which will light green colour and show you clues, your footprints and potential objects with which you can interact, flares which you need to defend yourself from ghosts and all scary things which surrounds you.

Game environment and levels are randomly generated for each time when you die or you simply load a latest checkpoint. Antagonists are randomly spawned aswel which will make you fear even more, every time.

Your goal in each level as it‚Äôs mentioned already is to search for notes and logs from the hospitals past, referred to as ‚Äúremnants‚Äù, by looking for markings using a glow stick. Sometimes by discovering remnants it will make marking on your arms which will attract what you simply dont want.

You have 2 choices, use your flare and make them disapear for couple seconds or run away as fast as you can without turning around. Sometimes it will take only one turn and it will appear in one corner, believe me you dont want to do that.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tXjg1NQxonQ

By exploring levels you will always find locked door and empty room with a lot of signes all over the place but once when you collect all remnants you will be able to acquire a ‚Äúsigil‚Äù, an item or significance for hospital past, teddy bear or a Bible for example. Once when you have your sigil you will need to run for a door without ability to use your flare or glowing stick which will tear fear in your bones and make your andrenalin go crazy.

Optimization is fairly good especially if you have on mind that this is first game on Unreal Engine 4, graphics are good but not so impressive and most of the time FPS is exactly where you want to be.

With all that being said it‚Äôs time to conclude this review.

For around 10 bucks you will get really amazing experiance from this horror game. Dont expect long adventure but you will get enough to be satisfied in all segments including atmosphere and storyline. Replay ability is always there with fact that levels will always be regenerated and random so you will definitely want to play couple times until you dont leave this title in your gaming library. My rating for this game is 85/100 when you look from all aspects which is fairly good and solid title. My recommendations without thinking twice.

reviewText:
Daylight is an Unreal Engine 4 powered survival horror game created by developer Zombie Studios that puts you into the shoes of a woman known only as Sarah. You‚Äôve been abandoned in a hospital with no recollection of how you got there or how you are supposed get out. You‚Äôre prompted by a voice to use your cellphone that acts as a combined GPS and flashlight to find all of the memories within the hospital which come in the form of scraps of paper, notes, and pictures. With the assistance of tools like glow sticks that highlight items of importance like boxes that contain items, valves, and switches; and flares that ward off enemies you make your way aimlessly through the rooms and corridors of this abandoned hospital.
First off I must address the elephant in the room. Daylight by Zombie Studios and Outlast by Red Barrels are indeed similar games and I expect comparisons will be drawn between the two. And as someone who has played through both; I‚Äôll be internally comparing them and this will show within this review.

Anyways, what sets Daylight apart from other games within the genre is the way it handles environments, enemies, content, and encounters. Daylight features a procedurally generated world and is touted to be the same experience twice. The layout of the hospital and prison, spawning of enemies, items you need to obtain and even how you complete these objectives are set to be different for every playthrough. Although some parts remain the same, specifically rooms with switches and the storage / break room, the rest of the environments are random. During my second playthrough I found myself trying to remember where I had gone the first time and this caused me to use up the most precious resource, flares. Speaking of flares, these items are the only things that can ward off enemies so it‚Äôs important to use them sparingly especially when the game scares you into using them when you didn‚Äôt truly need to. This leads directly into sound design and my oh my did Zombie Studios do a fantastic job with that. Daylight executes perfectly in balancing your fear level. Much like a good horror film you reach moments of tension that put you on the edge of your seat, and soon after are lulled into a false sense of safety before once again being put on edge. As you make your way through the halls of the hospital and prison you hear the telltale sound of an enemy approaching from behind you and this happens at random. But what happens is when you hear the sound of an enemy coming up from behind you; the enemy might not be there. This caused me to erroneously use my flares and left me without defenses when the enemies did come.

The phrase silent protagonist does not apply here as you are constantly updated with the thoughts and feelings of Sarah, you can hear her breathe heavily as the tension rises and even gasps out and yells when trouble is near. As you collect these memories you will occasionally hear the guiding voice which has just the right amount of creepy to leave you with that unsettling feeling. As enemies approach your cellphone, which acts as a mini-map that displays key locations and all the areas you‚Äôve explored begins to glitch and the map becomes difficult to see. Because the mini-map is in your hands there is a degree of difficulty in seeing it when you‚Äôre running which can cause you to walk into dead ends. Now normally this would be an issue in game like Outlast, but in Daylight if you end up cornering yourself you can run through the enemies. This broke the illusion for me, either Sarah is an Olympic distance runner with incredible stamina or the running is a little broken because this entire game can be run through including through and away from the enemies. While this certainly helped in my second playthrough, it completely killed the tension that is integral to what makes Daylight a survival horror game. This made the entire outside area a complete joke. Let it be noted that you can ‚Äúdie‚Äù in this game. Once I discovered I could just run away from the enemies I thought that it meant that nothing would happen if I stood still to let the enemies ‚Äúget me‚Äù. Of my two playthroughs I only died once and it was only to see if it could actually happen.

The entirety of my first playthrough lasted roughly two and a half hours, much of this time was spent reading every piece of paper and discovering all the memories that I could. But my second playthrough was completed after just 38 minutes. The game stops you from running through by forcing you to collect a certain amount of remnants that are scattered out throughout the level, once those remnants are collected you must then retrieve the ‚Äúsigil‚Äù, an item of important like a bible, or a teddy bear and bring that to the locked spooky gate. This is repeated four or five times and then the experience is over. It becomes a pattern that can be solved rather quickly and frankly it gets a little boring. The thing that would slow me down would be the layout of the hospital and prison solely because it is randomly generated.

On my first playthrough I ran into difficulties playing the game after reaching a waterfall area, if I was to look at the waterfall room directly my computer would completely lock up with the only solution being a hard reset. I got past this issue by looking at the ground and walking aimlessly until I found my way through that part. This was an odd issue that could only be replicated on my computer whose hardware was just a tiny bit better than the ‚Äúminimum‚Äù specifications required. However, on my second playthrough I used a computer that had exceeded the ‚Äúrecommended‚Äù specifications and only noticed a slight performance drop during this waterfall area. The biggest issue here is that it if you crash or stop playing at this waterfall junction; you are returned to the beginning of that section which takes a good 10-15 minutes to get back to. I am not deducting any points here for this, but it was something I had experienced in my review experience. This review was using a beta version of Daylight so this must also be taken into consideration.

Daylight is a great example of what a small dedicated team can do. Daylight will leave you feeling uneasy and wanting more. With excellent sound design and great looking environments thanks to Unreal Engine 4, Daylight should be a game that you‚Äôll want to play over and over, but because of the whole ‚Äúfind X number of items and proceed to the gate‚Äù mechanic you‚Äôll only want to play it once. On a second playthrough the game becomes a chore and what was creepy and scary in your first playthrough become a joke. Although you won‚Äôt get too much replayability I would still recommend anyone who enjoys the survival horror genre should give it a try. Daylight releases on April 29th for both PC and PlayStation 4 for just $15.00.

75/100
Good

reviewText: I'm going to be honest here for those of you who aren't set on wether to get this game or not.  Now, I'm not a person who gets scared easily at all.  This game in my opinion, is very slow paced;  Half the campaign is to get some teddy bear or key and raise it up in the air to open the next door and continue on and do the same.  Don't get me wrong though, it gave off very chilly vibes and the dialogue was astonishing.  On the other hand, the framerate I was getting on this game was a little lower than expected. reviewText:
For now I can't really reccomend this game to anyone, except horror fans who allready finished everything in genre.

1.It took me a few days to run the game. Weird errors, crushing last Nvidia drivers, not being able to close the hanging application (and having to restart PC) - all this was really disappointing. But, hey I DID manage to run the game in the end, right? Have no clue how - one day it just start working. Before that I tried to reinstall drivers and checked my directX, read forums, etc. - didn't help. Both 1.0 and 1.1 versions didn't work. Now 1.1 does.

2. The game is generic and not scary. Play Outlast, Amnesia or first Silent Hills for scares. Monster (s) are not scary, scares are not scary, protagonists remarks are the same all the time and it breaks the atmosphere.

3. Graphics are so-so. I mean, this suppose to be U4 engine? Not inspiring textures, so-so lighting, etc. Of course, it is indie project. But why U4? Sometimes Unity games looks better. And most of the time I hold a glow-stick. So the game is green for the most of the time...

4. Running. All you do in game is run. From room to room. That's it. No hiding, no fighting, no jumping. Running only.

I'm a horror fan and I have nothing (horrible) to play. So I'll finish this game. Because of the story. Till now it's kinda interesting. But I can't recommend this game for the average player. Horror fans only. And only if you have nothing to play.

P.S.: It's not a proper game. More like a spatial storytelling case study. Game design teachers would be happy to play it. The game utilizes technology to create media-unique experience. But it lacks personality, emotions and characters to care for.

EDIT: Finished the game. Dumb writing. Can't understand what really happened in the game, who is the voice, talking to main character, etc.

reviewText:
This game is not worth the current asking price.  For starters, it is way too short.  Depending on whether you hold down the sprint key or take your time, the game can be anywhere between an hour and a half to two and a half hours long.  You have infinite sprint and using it allows you to escape enemies, so there is no reason not to hold down sprint all the time unless you want to soak in the atmosphere.  Taking your time makes things a bit scarier and so I recommend it, but later on this game will not allow you to do that anyway.  It sabotages itself by forcing you to be constantly running when it would be much better to build up suspense by allowing you to slow down.

The next major problem it has is that there is no variety in the gameplay.  You must walk around and locate a pre-set number of notes marked by red glowing symbols.  Once you collect enough notes, an item will appear.  You must collect the item and carry it to a door where it will allow you to proceed to the next area.  Then you must repeat this process again.  Once you do this about 5 or 6 times, the game is over.

There is also only one enemy in the game and it infinitely re-spawns, meaning you will very quickly get used to it.  It's genuinely scary for at least the first 2 levels, but after that, the enemy is thrown at you so often that it becomes more annoying than anything else.

The developers tried to throw in other scares such as loud noises, hallucination sequences, and objects being moved in front of you.  These are frightening the first few times but are used so often that they also become old very fast.

Overall, this game was a disappointment.  It was genuinely scary at first but quickly got old.  Buy it, but only on sale for at least 66% off.  Don't pay full price for it.

reviewText: It took me about two days to even get this game to work, which didn't exactly put me on any good footing for it. Then when I actually got into it... there was about an hour of gameplay with nothing but cheap jumpscares.  Atmosphere is alright, but it wears thin when you realize 'procedurally generated' means using the same four or five cells over and over for each area in a nonsensical pattern (which I suppose is good for fans of the Cube movies).
