reviewText:
It's not a bad game.

Not a great game, but not a bad game. I do recommend it, but wait for a sale.

It's basically something of a cross between Slender page collection, and Outlasts exploration.

You wander hallways and tunnels that are randomly generated each time, looking for remnants of the past of the area you're in, to find a key to open a door to the next area, repeat a few times until the end.

There's the odd simple puzzle, but the 'meat' of the gameplay is along the scavenging.

I did enjoy the game, but I feel it's not worth 15 bucks USD. Wait for at least 5 dollar markdown.

reviewText:
Not a bad game. In fact, I'm enjoying it.

The game does manage to build tense moments, scares and even frightens - I've run from a few ghosts several times. At times, I couldn't help but feel like something was lurking behind me, and sometimes there was.

My only complaint is that Sarah, the main character, speaks. Maybe the devs thought this would immerse the player, but it does the opposite and makes me aware of the developer. Yes, Sarah, I know someone (or something) is there. I'm thinking about it as I play.

I picked this up for $10 on a pre-order. No regrets.

reviewText:
Not a full review yet, I'm not really into supernatural horror. I'm more of a sci-fi/fantasy horror guy; stuff like Resident Evil and Left 4 Dead. Mainly because the jump scares are less something lurking around the corner or that huge beast that busted through the door, but something running across a doorway or something magically appearing behind you. I kind of hate that.

For starters, since I only just got started, I can say this game doesn't scream next-gen, but it subtly whispers it to you. You'll notice no jaggies or sharp edges popping out at you. And I don't even remember there being a tessellation setting. The game performs well on a 7970@1440p only stuttering occasionally, otherwise the slowness seems more a design choice as even with the controller sensitivity cranked up. You can imagine a game with this engine that has a superior art team.

Update: After playing a while, it's okay, kind of creepy--dig the atmosphere--but again, I don't really like these types of scares. Some of the level design indoors seem very repetitive, like I had no idea aside from the map where to go because it all started to look alike. I read somebody say it was partially randomly generated, but why? The levels are pretty small.

And there are levels" you can clear. It seems like a better design choice would have been to have an open mansion or hospital or whatever. You use your glowstick
date: find 4 remnants in the first two stages and them find the special item I can't remember the name of. Level clear. Whatever. I was more interested in the game as a no combat thriller using Unreal 4 than I was of it being an actual game.\n\nAt $10 perhaps I'd recommend it like a phone or tablet game. I'm going to play it like a casual horror game to pass time
recommended: get a few scares and enjoy Unreal 4.\n\nI had to get this
hoursPlayed: even with the Unreal 4 demoes available I had to just see what it can do. Now I'm semi-excited for Arkham Knight
voteText: even though it's a console optimized game. Hopefully they'll allow PC gamers to ratchet up the settings as they see fit. I will say this game immediately makes the fans on my 7970 spin up. I guess Unreal 4 must be more parallel as it must immediately start to put the card to work just for stuff like lighting calculations alone. I hope devs keep pushing our cards like this with well optimized games so PC can stand above console legitimately

reviewText:
I'll be giving this game a thumbs up but just barely.
Reason why is because though it isn't the greatest of games, it certianly isn't the worst game that people have been calling it for the past few months. I can see some of the negatives that people are talking about but here's the Pros and Cons I found about the game and I'm sure you'll be surprised:

Pros -
- Some scares actually do make you jump and the dark hallways do give you the sense of dread.
- The controls are soild as a rock. Nothing needs changing about them because the gameplay is actually really decent.
- The mechanics of the game like trying to shine a light on the item you need to look for is pretty cool.
- The levels are pretty neat in their design.

Cons -
- The scares can get old very fast but still might give you a jump from time to time.
- The graphics for a game using the latest Unreal Engine is pretty disappointing because the game really doesn't look that great.
- Some of map layouts can be confusing as all hell.
- Voice acting = D Movie level of cheese.

Overall:
The game really isn't that bad but be warned though, I'd recommend you get this game at least 5 pounds because at the price it's at now it's still a caution buy.

reviewText:
When you walk into a room and a faucet turns on, or a wheel chair moves, it all plays into the terror the game is eliciting from you. Additionally, this game has new content generated through each play-through. So, every time you restart, the layout will be different, remnants will be in new locations, and these beings won‚Äôt pop out in the same places‚Äîall ensuring the element of surprise is in the opposing hands. This, unfortunately, comes at the expense of longevity in a single playthrough ‚Äì you could be disappointed to find out that the game can be completed in 1.5/2 hours, and while there are reasons to replay it, it still seems a bit too low considering the price tag.

Overall, I would say that Daylight‚Äôs shortcomings are overshadowed by the way this game scares the absolute crap out of the player. This game is one of the few that stay true to the genre, while reviving it in the same instance. My advice to prospective players: run
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is supposed to be a randomly-generated horror game that builds tension through immersion.

** Randomly generated environments do not work when all of the things you generate are so fungible they're indistinguishable.
** Horror does not work when the story is too shallow and the premise for said horror is never adequately explained.
** Tension does not work when there is insufficient pacing to generate anticipation, instead of constant running.
** Immersion does not work when there are only four different ways you can interact with your environment.

By the end of an utterly anemic run through, I had no idea who the protagonist was, no sense of why I should care about her, no horror or fright that extended beyond predictable jump-scares, no desire to play through again, and a profound sense of disappointment.  Not worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
‚ÄúDaylight‚Äù should have been left in the dark.

This survival horror game leaves players in the dark with a serious lack of direction, but does contain music that will inspire the fear of darkness. There is very little to offer in this horror game except a marketing tool. ‚ÄúDaylight‚Äù will frustrate you just as much as it will frighten you.

‚ÄúDaylight‚Äù places players in an abandoned hospital, where they play as a woman named Sarah. She wakes up clueless and disoriented, with only a cell phone and a few glow sticks and flares to guide her in the dark. With only a mysterious voice giving her vague clues, she must explore the hospital and discover its history before she is able to escape.

This kind of story has been told before in survival horror games, and ‚ÄúDaylight‚Äù hardly offers anything different. With a worn-out setting like a hospital, one can already expect things like evil doctors and crazy patients, making things predictable.

The gameplay is simple and easy to learn. Players have to use their cell phone light, glow sticks and flares to navigate through the dark halls of the hospital. Shadow people will randomly appear throughout the hospital as the game moves on. Being caught by them is almost an instant game over. Players can run away or toss a flare at them to make them disappear.

Players will have a difficult time figuring out what to do, as the game provides no clear indication of what to do or where to go. The clues provided are vague and will have you literally running around in the dark hoping you‚Äôre on the right track.

A big problem with ‚ÄúDaylight‚Äù is the lack of a save function. Players can only save their progress by reaching a checkpoint. There is no indication of where or when you have arrived at one, making it frustrating when the shadow people catch you.

The game‚Äôs music and sound is frightfully amazing. It‚Äôs eerie and quiet, and the unsettling sounds mixed with the subtle but tense music really pulls you in the game‚Äôs world. When you run, you can hear the soles of your shoes scratching the floor. The audio cue for nearby shadow people is a quick and loud screeching, making the player look around at where they are coming from. ‚ÄúDaylight‚Äù gets the music and sounds right, but doesn‚Äôt make up for the game‚Äôs lack of direction.

‚ÄúDaylight‚Äù was something that should have never seen the light of day. It offers nothing new or unique to the genre. Players can stumble through the game in about three hours and leave it in the dark after they are finished. It is exclusive to PS4 and PC. Even priced at a measly $15, I still suffer from buyer‚Äôs remorse.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
(Personal Score & Reasons to buy down below)

Daylight promised a lot of things, and most of those things weren't delivered. But let's not focus on what it should have been, but on what it is. I am a huge horror fan, and I have probably played most of the horror games out there, or at least tried them.

Daylight is procedurally generated, which is a double edged sword, on one hand, you have supposedly unlimited ways to get scared, but here lies one of the biggest gripes of the game for me: there's not enough variation on the scares. 30 minutes in I had experienced most of the random scares more than once each. The same whispers play over and over, there's only a number of times that a chair moving or something falling will be scary, and then there are some very awful jump scares. So it got tiresome a bit. What kept the game very tense and kept me on edge at times was the sound design and a couple of times where the witch was chasing me. That said, the ambience is top notch, and so is the soundtrack and sound design.

Another gripe I have with the game is that the main character talks too much. Again, there's only a number of times that you can hear your character (for whom you feel nothing) comment on something or just saying I know you're in here!" - which totally breaks immersion. That said

recommended: since I felt it gave a bit of humanity to the character

reviewText:
When you walk into a room and a faucet turns on, or a wheel chair moves, it all plays into the terror the game is eliciting from you. Additionally, this game has new content generated through each play-through. So, every time you restart, the layout will be different, remnants will be in new locations, and these beings won‚Äôt pop out in the same places‚Äîall ensuring the element of surprise is in the opposing hands. This, unfortunately, comes at the expense of longevity in a single playthrough ‚Äì you could be disappointed to find out that the game can be completed in 1.5/2 hours, and while there are reasons to replay it, it still seems a bit too low considering the price tag.

Overall, I would say that Daylight‚Äôs shortcomings are overshadowed by the way this game scares the absolute crap out of the player. This game is one of the few that stay true to the genre, while reviving it in the same instance. My advice to prospective players: run
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is supposed to be a randomly-generated horror game that builds tension through immersion.

** Randomly generated environments do not work when all of the things you generate are so fungible they're indistinguishable.
** Horror does not work when the story is too shallow and the premise for said horror is never adequately explained.
** Tension does not work when there is insufficient pacing to generate anticipation, instead of constant running.
** Immersion does not work when there are only four different ways you can interact with your environment.

By the end of an utterly anemic run through, I had no idea who the protagonist was, no sense of why I should care about her, no horror or fright that extended beyond predictable jump-scares, no desire to play through again, and a profound sense of disappointment.  Not worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
I would love to tell you more about this title.  However, the game is so unstable and crashes so often that I can't get into the game very far, which is a SUPER huge disappointment.

From what I can tell you, Daylight consists of wondering corridors and hallways.  Periodically, pictures move, lights flicker, and wheelchairs roll past your path.  The story seems disjointed as do the characters reactions to most of what happens.  The mystique of an unfolding plot with interesting material is not really apparent in the game as far as I've played it.  Additionally, for having used the latest greatest Unreal Engine, the game doesn't look much better than say Metro Last Light.  In fact it looks worse in my opinion but runs much worse.

Overall, a huge disappointment of a title.

TL:DR:  Incredibly unstable and buggy (expect crashes), disjointed reactions from the character, lack of interesting plot dynamics, and HUGE system requirements but looks less impressive and runs worse than other games with similar requirements.

reviewText:
This is a great game for first time horror players. For anyone who has finished a game like Amnisia or Outlast however, this may get a little slow paced after about an hour or so. The feeling of 'i'm in danger' is less present than 'i'm really lost,' most of the time.
-Visuals take a little getting used to but they are fine, the effects of the different light sources are cool and the glitching of your map could be a challenge if your trying to move fast and forgotten the layout of the area.
-Gameply is basicly this: Explore, memorize routs, Find objects to uncover the story, fing the 'level key', and bring it to the sealed door. This seems to repeat, however at this point I have only gotten past two levels before wanting to get back to playing Dark Souls II...

So a good game for horror noobs, but may be blan for vetrans of the genre. If you like mystery, this game has a lot of not knowing exactly what is going on.

So on the bright side this game is creepy at first. Things go bump, and you hear noises and apparitions sometimes appear behind you or at the end of a hall providing a good jump scare.

reviewText: If you like your games to be super repetitive and lacking in atmosphere, then this is for you. It's much like being caught in one of thoe Maize Mazes in the countryside in summer. At first they are ok but it soon wears off as you go around and around, looking at the same thing, over and over. Yet, with Daylight we get a story, which isn't much. I played this for about an 40 mins and basically I couldn't take anymore. The graphics are really poor, despite having everything set on max and having a good system to run it on. I was hoping that given that this was one of the firsr games to use the new engine we would see something different, but instead it's really rather poor. Granted the game is cheap, but seriously, there are much better games on Steam and elsewhere that deserve your money. Polygon rated this as a 5 and I thought that perhaps they were being harsh. In reality, they were being generous. This is quite easily one of the worst games I've played of this genre, come to think of it, of any genre.

reviewText:
its not even about the game being the same as all the other horror games. it just doesnt seem well put together for me. i dont know why this bothers me as much as it does, but it reallllllly takes away from the fear factor of the game....pull out a glowstick, look down and walk backwards. with each foot step you see 2 sets of feet landing on the ground as  if the person is hopping around. with horror games, if you want them to be effective, then you need attention to detail. small subtle things to build up suspense...not something that is going to keep me from wanting to look down due to how annoyed ill become.

i realllllly wanted to like this game. i was super super stoked about it coming out and finally being released...but it just isnt what i thought it was going to be. the reason amnesia, pnumbra and outlast were so successful is because they paid attention to detail. comparing other games to it isnt a bad thing because they set a milestone for what other games should strive to be like.

I understand that a lot of love and care was put into this game...it just ultimately feels like a modded version of some other game. I wouldnt recommend it.

reviewText:
Not a full review yet, I'm not really into supernatural horror. I'm more of a sci-fi/fantasy horror guy; stuff like Resident Evil and Left 4 Dead. Mainly because the jump scares are less something lurking around the corner or that huge beast that busted through the door, but something running across a doorway or something magically appearing behind you. I kind of hate that.

For starters, since I only just got started, I can say this game doesn't scream next-gen, but it subtly whispers it to you. You'll notice no jaggies or sharp edges popping out at you. And I don't even remember there being a tessellation setting. The game performs well on a 7970@1440p only stuttering occasionally, otherwise the slowness seems more a design choice as even with the controller sensitivity cranked up. You can imagine a game with this engine that has a superior art team.

Update: After playing a while, it's okay, kind of creepy--dig the atmosphere--but again, I don't really like these types of scares. Some of the level design indoors seem very repetitive, like I had no idea aside from the map where to go because it all started to look alike. I read somebody say it was partially randomly generated, but why? The levels are pretty small.

And there are levels" you can clear. It seems like a better design choice would have been to have an open mansion or hospital or whatever. You use your glowstick
date: find 4 remnants in the first two stages and them find the special item I can't remember the name of. Level clear. Whatever. I was more interested in the game as a no combat thriller using Unreal 4 than I was of it being an actual game.\n\nAt $10 perhaps I'd recommend it like a phone or tablet game. I'm going to play it like a casual horror game to pass time
recommended: get a few scares and enjoy Unreal 4.\n\nI had to get this
hoursPlayed: even with the Unreal 4 demoes available I had to just see what it can do. Now I'm semi-excited for Arkham Knight
voteText: even though it's a console optimized game. Hopefully they'll allow PC gamers to ratchet up the settings as they see fit. I will say this game immediately makes the fans on my 7970 spin up. I guess Unreal 4 must be more parallel as it must immediately start to put the card to work just for stuff like lighting calculations alone. I hope devs keep pushing our cards like this with well optimized games so PC can stand above console legitimately

reviewText: Open the windows folks! Talk about a stinker... Daylight reminds me of the old Quake II Mods in it's simplicity and looks. It's scary for a second and then it's done. Daylight is akin to a knock knock joke, when you hear it the first time you laugh... the second time, you groan... the third time you just want to punch the person telling it in the face. In Daylight,  once you see the spooky, Ring girl once, it creeps you out, you laugh and the game is over; because after the first time she scares you - well, that's it, the surprises are done and it's the same thing over and over and over and over and over.... You get the point. Save yourself some time and money by having a kid tell you a knock knock joke and then go play Myst instead of buying, installing and playing" this hunk-a-jalopy. You will get more far more entertainment that way. Glad this bomb came free with a vid card.\n\nPS
date: why this game required the Unreal 4 engine is beyond me... This game could have been made with the same engine they use for the game SIN

reviewText: Daylight is a horror game that was created to freak the players out but will it scare you or will you want to go play a better horror game ? In Daylight you play as Sarah, she wakes up in a hostpital and you hear a mysterious voice of a doctor that guides you to Daylight. So how is this game ? This game is not worth your time. Now lets go through the pros and cons. The pros: The atmosphere is amazing it really feels lonely and scary in these kinda places. Controls are fluid and simple to use. Unique approach to the horror genre. But thats all of it thats good about this game. Now about the bad. The game is a maze and the map on the phone barely helps so no point in using it you will have much more luck wandering around. The game is short you can pretty much beat it in an hour. The story is consisted of scraps which you have to find to understand the story. Boring objectives which are always the same. Overall Daylight is a pretty mediocre horror game which i cant recommend. Daylight gets a 5/10

reviewText:
Female protagonist, scary, easy to play, replayable, and creepy.  It has everything I wanted for a decent price.  It's not anything that's going to change the genre or something you *MUST* experience.  It certainly delivered on anything advertised and *I* enjoyed it.  The replayability of it is part of the fun, as I can't memorize the maps and such.  Even dying and respawning, would change parts of the puzzles into different areas.

Now, for the more depth review.  You wake up with a cell phone and some guy talking to you presumably through the cell phone.  You get glowsticks that you can use which will highlight things you can get.  You get flares that you can use that burn ghosts and such.  Those are the basics, the puzzles are simple, I almost always had a glowstick out as they were very numerous, and only ran out of flares once at where I ended up dying.

Dodging the ghosts is simple, you can usually hear them and turn your back to them and walk past them backwards or whatever, it seems you must look at them for them to be able to kill you.  You can run past them and a whole lot of things.  No hiding places like in Outlast, that I could find.  The game is ridiculously simple.  You just progress by finding remnants" (basically information written by people)

recommended: you then need to find the "sigil" which acts as a key to enter a puzzle area

reviewText:
A scary game to be sure, though not as scary as the likes of Amnesia or Outlast. It's also a good looking game, but a little power-hungry; Likely due to UE4's DX11 effects.

Daylight is a game of discovery, so I highly recommend playing without any advance knowledge or expectations. That's how I went into it, and I enjoyed it much more than I would have otherwise. Expect a 2-4hr playthrough.

The checkpoint-saving system can be annoying due to a lack of Save and Quit" option
date: but you learn to deal with it. Also
recommended: you can't rebind the controls. They're basic WASD
hoursPlayed: but still."

I also heard some whispers that, i swear to god, sounded like 'I will suck your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•', and i really am serious.
You can throw glowsticks and they will float 2-3cm above the ground, and there is a voice that gives you indications and the same guy is watching you at that time, and he sounds like hugh heffner or some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

I laughed a bit, and i am not mad because it sucks balls, because i actually wanted to give this away...

reviewText:
I haven't really played it enough to pass any sort of real judgement on it, but so far so good and certainly scary enough :creep:

I can speak about the technical part though...

It really needs some collision detection polishing, especially with lighting going completely off when near objects and your own footprints are stretch over objects you didn't even walk over.

The (feels like) fixed 30fps, which makes it feel too games console toy like, which is both hard on the eyes and fluidity of the game.

Very limiting controls. A part from just the typical WASD, you have just a few other options (flare, glowstick, throw and map. Once something is opened, you can go back to it, to pick the items left and if you throw your glowstick (when you crack it), you can't pick it up again.

No 8Ch (7.1) audio support only 6Ch (5.1) which is OK, but for a game of this genre and using sound a great deal it's shame it doesn't output above the typical 6Ch.

For some odd reason it uses the same amount of systems resources whether I play in Stereo SBS 3D (2x 1920x1080), Oculus Rift v1 or standard old school (1x 1920x1080) with none hitting above 30fps (fixed fps?)

Many are having technical problems with the game or feel it doesn't look like much. A few things to note, the game was built on Windows 8, 64bit architecture, DirectX 11 and ran on at least an Nvidia GTX 6 series (and above). Compare it to anything less than this and the game looks very different, plays poorly and downgraded (will look and play like a games console game ...ewww) :Eye_tv:

Final review TBC

reviewText:
Daylight is all about procedurally generated levels in a first person horror view. Which tries oh so hard to be scary, only to fail after the first 30 mins into the game. Its more of a first person adventure game, or hidden object than a horror. It has more of a fun house at a carnival feel than a horror game. The story is written so weak to where I don't know whats going on and nor does it ever make you feel like your part of it. Nothing but cheap jump scares which lose their power very fast, even more so once you realize how worthless and weak the ghosts are.

reviewText:
Here it is ... DayLight !
I preordered it for only 10‚Ç¨, and i can tell you that i'm proud to have bought it !

I have played maybe all horror games that exist, from Dead Space to Slender The Arrival, or OUTLAST etc...then i played this one, first of all :
- This game is a real Engine Showcase ! It shows perfectly the whole new Unreal Engine 4 ! Which is absolutly awesome ! Depth of Field is so realistic, as the lights and the awesome shadows (Real time, of course ! )

-No bindings !!! This is a thing that should be fixed quickly, i managed to change them by heading to the Main folder of the game and manually change them
for further information : (QWERTY TO AZERTY)
First go in your DayLight Folder, located in Steam/Steamapps/Common
First to edit the movement, edit the file named BaseInput.ini" located in Engine/config/
Find the lines :

+AxisMappings=(AxisName="MoveForward"
hoursPlayed: Key=S
voteText: Scale=-1.f)\n+AxisMappings=(AxisName="MoveForward"
votesHelpful: Scale=1.f)\n+AxisMappings=(AxisName="MoveForward"
votesFunny: Scale=-1.f)\n+AxisMappings=(AxisName="MoveForward"
commentsCount: Key=Gamepad_LeftY
column16: Scale=1.f)\n\n+AxisMappings=(AxisName="MoveRight"
column17: Key=A
column18: Scale=-1.f)\n+AxisMappings=(AxisName="MoveRight"
column19: Key=D
column20: Scale=1.f)\n+AxisMappings=(AxisName="MoveRight"
column39: right handed !\nif you are like me and left handed
column40: do the same and replace only the Q and D key with "Left" for Q and "Right" for D (No quotes
column41:
and yes it is inversed with the AxisName)




Then
column42: let's speak about the Game itself
column43: i finished it of course !\n+The game has an amazing ambient
column44: sounds are perfect and match perfectly with the environment !\n+So scary !! Probably one of the scariest game i played ! The ghost haunting you is just horrible and his moving are good
column46: he can jumpscares you ! I also like the sounds he makes when he is right behind you
column47: threatening !\n+ The price ! Of course 10‚Ç¨ is nothing compared to this game !\n+ The maps : Every maps is generated randomly
column48: this means you can never have exactly the same maps
column50: or some rooms) but are placed randomly in those corridors. Otherwise
column51: it is now no more possible to fallow a youtuber like Pewds or anyone else and playing the game without understanding anything
column53: this has a great impact on the hours you will pass on this game
column54: a lot of replaying possibilities !\n+ Achievement
column56: makes you pass longer hour on the game
column57: some are hard as hell !\n+ Difficulty : The difficulty is changeable
column58: to fit better with your experience
column59:
try Hard mode without destroying your pants !


Now what is bad in this game ? Here :
-Bindings (See on top)
-Short ! Story to short ! But replayable
-Problems with DX11
....................and thats all !

17/20

reviewText:
Awsome game. I crap myself out. Scares you when you dont expect it. As it is expected -.- A little bit too short for delaying it that much. I finished the game in 1 and a half hour. Graphics are outstanding.

While the graphics are outstanding I can't say the same for the in-game mechanics. Don't get me wrong. They are smooth as hell, but they don't give you the freedom you payed for ;) EX.: You can't crouch. Neither jump. Just run ,push and climb.

Another flaw of the game is that if you stay were you are and the entity is behind you can stay there and she/he will be gone. So there's no point if she/he follows and then he/she goes away because you didn't turn around.

Apart from that the overall game is interesting. I bought it when it was 9.99 bucks so it worth it. I give it a 6/10.

reviewText:
Wow Daylight, truely a horrifying game.  I personally found this game scarier than any other game I've played before.  I haven't gotten around to finishing the game on this account but I played through the game while hanging with mates and they definitely enjoyed torturing me throughout the game as they knew the game was getting to me.

There are a lot of horror games out there but I would definitely say that Daylight would be the scariest one.  My first time playing the game did not go very well as that was done on this account, the game scared me quite quickly to the point where I actually quit and decided to play another game.  My mates eventually talked me into playing through it while I was hanging with them and the horror value of the game stayed high throughout the game.

This game may not inflict the fear in other players but it definitely did a good job at scaring me and I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a good horror game.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This was an impulse buy. I dont usually do that ever...but I've been following this game for awhile.  It seems promising. Procedurally generated levels every time you play = differant game every time.  Scary setting with nothing but a phone light and glow sticks to protect you. Seemed pretty interesting.  I played it for about an hour wasn't terribly impressed.  I was a bit scared at times sure, but not terrified as I wandered the hospital looking for items.

Gameplay revolves around going from floor to floor finding notes. Once you've found 6 notes on for each level or board" you go to a certain room that has an item of one of the insane people. You pick it up and carry it to a special locked door that allows you to progress to the next "board".

That in a nutshell is the gameplay. Along the way you find glowsticks that show hints if you really need that.  All you do is click on everything
hoursPlayed: cupboards
voteText: whatever.  It gets very tedious very quickly.  There are some jump scares but  those are all that will get you the least bit frightened.  I only paid 10 bucks for it so its not terrible for a game like this. I just doubt i'll get 10 hours of enjoyment.  More like 2.  That equals 5 bucks per hour of entertainment. I guess for a video game thats not terrible
helpfulPercent: I just would've wanted more gameplay variety.\n\nFor a game like this it works
votesHelpful: it really does. Its not annoying like outlast
votesTotal: where your camera light runs out of batteries after 5-6 minutes. You dont have to worry about battery power. You don't worry really about much at all.  Just click on all the doors
votesFunny: explore the hospital and pick up all the notes.\n\nIn conclusion I think its not a terrible buy.  Get it now while its on sale. Its not worth more than 10 bucks."

reviewText:
Hrmm... I really wanted to like this game. Very disappointed.

1. Stutters terribly. Very low framerate (10-20 fps).
This is on a i7 processor with a Nvidia GT545 card with 8gb RAM.
Same computer plays Arma 3 at native 1920x1080 at 45-50 fps & Outlast at same, gfx set to high at 40-45 fps

2. Non-programable controls.
What decade are the Devs stuck in? I use a Razor Nostromo that is already setup for up, down, left, right and custom keys that I use for all my other FPS games. Suddenly you force me to use WASD? Thats fine if you're developing at Flash game. For crying out loud Doom and Wolfenstein 3d allowed for custom control configs.

I tried to play this for about 3 hours maybe and spent most of my time trying to figure out what was worng with the engine and framerate/stutter when looking left-right issue. I have DX11.1, latest drivers, low textures, low res.... every setting imaginable = no joy. Finally gave up.

I've waited a month to see if the Devs would complete this botched launch. Sadly they have not. I would like the money back (14.99) BUT not from Steam. I would like the Devs (Zombie Studios) to cut me a check as I feel they knowingly foisted an incomplete product with a broken engine onto the unsuspecting Valve guys. All I can say is to wait a while and thoroughly review the forums and reviews before purchasing.

reviewText:
A shallow story that is dully told by a protagonist with no personality or discernable characteristics whatsoever and an almost abscent and clich√© narrator in an unimpressive nightmare world.

The ambiance is quite creepy, i'll give you that, until you notice the whole scenery in each stage is just a copy and paste of the same sections over and over  game, making a confusing maze, yes, but also a boooooring one.

Moving objects are not enough to scare anyone these days. The only actual frightening thing is the only thing that can kill you: The nurses ghosts... but that's the only enemy in the game... and there's only 1 way of repelling it... and it gets old really soon.

The game is linear and short, and there's no involvement whatsoever, you NEVER feel any empathy towards the protagonist or what's happening.

And the ending.... there's no ending... just a stupid final phrase and a still illustrations aaaaaaand credits roll.

No use in re-playing it. Not recommended. Maybe some jumpy players will enjoy a couple of jump scares, but for anyone who has enjoyed terror games such as silent hill or fatal frame, this will come as a waste of money.

reviewText:
Don't pay 15 dollars for this.  It is enjoyable, but has it's problems.  It's slender meets Outlast.  Find the pages, get the thingy, run like hell to the exit.

It is definatly creepy and scary, although not as much as hyped.  It's fun but nothing groundbreaking.  It is also short.  I beat it under 3 hours knowing nothing of the gameplay/tricks.

other annoyances (minor) non rebindable keys,  early level is quit confusing to navigate, and if you attempt to get an item you have too many of, it vanishes into thin air, so you can't come back and get it later.

If you can grab it for five bucks or less, it's worth it.  I got it free with a GPU purchase, but it's not worth the current price IMO.

reviewText:
Traditional Rating - 52/100
Recommendation - Buy on SALE, horror fans
Tagline - Decent for what it is
If I had played a demo - I would have purchased

I actually kind of enjoyed this game.

First things first though, THIS IS NOT OUTLAST. It does not pretend to be Outlast, and I highly doubt it was ever intended to be compared to Outlast (even though it is, rather frequently). Sure, it's in an asylum as well, but that's hardly an original idea on Outlast's part. As for the light source, in Outlast, the camera was useless until you held it up to your face to record and/or switch the nightvision on; in Daylight, the phone light is on all the time and does nothing other than map the area. In reality, the phone in Daylight is functionally closer to the lantern in Amnesia.

Basically, this game is NOTHING like Outlast.

If you ask me, this game plays much more similarly to that Slenderman game where you're gathering pages in the woods (right down to how you gather remnants in each area before performing a ritual and moving on). Compared to Outlast, this game is the epitome of lameness, but when compared to that Slenderman game (which I did not care for in the slightest), it is rather brilliant.

Taken as a whole on its own, the game is rather middling, but it sets out to tell a story (which it does, even if it is cliche as hell) and make you jump (which it also does). I figured out all the tricks by about the halfway point, but I still had fun in the later chapters, even if part of that was laughing at its B-movie nature.

Don't take this as a glowing endorsement, though. There are quite a few serious issues with the game. It is not very well-optimized, there are loading-induced stutters and frame drops GALORE, the times when the dialog kicks in are often nonsensical (and hilariously immersion-breaking), the story is opaque from a mile away, you rinse-repeat the same exact actions in all 5 areas, and the game is too easy (although they would have had to be smart about making it more difficult).

The reason for my last parenthetical is that, should you die, you awaken" back at the entrance to your current area with none of the remnants you picked up
date: and you have to do the ENTIRE section over again. It would have been MUCH smarter if they instituted a manual save game feature like so many other horror games. Case in point
recommended: I had to attempt the 3rd area 3 times
hoursPlayed: and I was so annoyed by the 3rd try that I was beyond scaring.\n\nThe game does a few things pretty well too
voteText: though. While there are copious amounts of blur
votesHelpful: and focus issues preventing you from seeing them
votesTotal: the graphics are actually quite pretty. This is the first game to use the Unreal Engine 4
votesFunny: and if you look closely enough
commentsCount: you can see the subtle upgrades over UE3. Also
column16: the menu theme is interesting
column17: if not entirely memorable. I've tried to think of a 3rd good thing to say
column18: but I can't.\n\nI can't say this was my favorite horror game of all time
column19: or even in the top 5 (maybe even 10)
column20: but if you're a horror fan and you understand it for what it is
column21: you should get a decent amount of fun out of it.\n\nDO NOT pay $15 for it though. The entire thing is about 2 hours long
column22: even with having to replay some areas."

reviewText:
First of all, i dont understand why alot of people had issues running the game.
It clearly said GTX 470 or up, and the error message tells you to update win7, thats what i did and thats how the game started to run for me without any problems this far, except for one freeze only.

about the game itself, its the first Unreal Engine 4 game to be released and i have to say, i like what i see.
some of the reviews here say it looks like some bad UT3 mod or something, but i doubt they played it on the highest specs.
the game itself is running on Dx11 basis and you can add some neat effects, like HBAO + which is considered a next gen feature.
the physic effects look nice and add to the creepy atmosphere, altough the textures could be a little better at some places.

the gameplay was enjoyable for me so far, didnt make much progress, but there was enough difference, i didnt have to see the same doors and walls over and over again, it can also be very scary when you know somethings coming closer, but you dont know where its coming from. youll be surprised by some really terrifying looking ghost.

this game does what its supposed to do:
be next gen, be a scary maze/puzzle/survival game, that actually really changes whenever you load it up and look good doing it. the sounds and the creepy atmosphere really add up to it.

reviewText:
Let those who argue about 'definitive' in the genre.  What this game has taught me is a far greater lesson.  The lesson is that I don't care for survival horror.

It's not that I get freaked out by video games from time to time.  A jump scare is fun sometimes.  It's not that this is necessarily a bad game.  It could be very good in its genre.  But outside of Code Veronica, this game has galvanized that I do not enjoy the genre.  I don't get scared by the monster chasing me in the hall.  I don't get scared by the popup ghosts.  I just don't get scared.  I get curious, I work through the motions of investigating or leaving, but that's about it.  The genre becomes less of a game and more of a chore.   I'm the one that's broken, but this game has showed me it's me.

As for the game itself, I can't give it a negative review.  It has a good atmosphere that it's aiming for.  There's plenty of backstory to fill in with all those papers left around.  Graphically and audibly it was pleasing.  Possibly I could appreciate it further in VR or 3D (this game seems to heavily support those kinds of options).  As it stands, it seems to have direction and only climbing the boxes felt truly tedious.

The fact that the levels are supposed to be procedurally generated by some degree should lend some replayability to this game.

But, I've found this isn't my genre so you may want to shop around other reviews.

reviewText:
My early first impressions of, Daylight:

Technical problems aside, and yes there are a lot of technical problems, my early first impressions of Daylight as far as the game itself is concerned, is that it is a horror game masterpiece. And just a video game masterpiece in general.

The main number one reason why I say this is because Daylight is a procedurally generated video game which means that things are different each time you play. Procedurally generated video games are a work of absolute genius.

Because what this means for Daylight is tons of re-play value.

I personally don't re-play the majority of games that I have. I'll play through most of my games once and then move on to something else, especially the ones that are heavily scripted. I find scripted video games to be the worst. Because after you learn the patterns of a scripted video game, it gets boring after a while because you know exactly what is going to happen.

For example the original un-modded version of Doom 3 which is heavily scripted. You know that no matter what, no matter how many times you play through the game, this monster is going to show up at this exact same location, that monster is going to show up at that same exact location once you reach the certain areas to trigger them to spawn.

Daylight is a whole different story. With each play through, things are different. The notes are in different locations. The sound effects are different. The monsters spawn at different times and different locations. The layout of the map is different. The glow sticks and flares are in different locations. All of this is just absolutely incredible. This keeps Daylight fresh and new at all times. Plus it makes the game even more scary because you never know exactly what's going to happen next because the monsters spawn at random with each playthrough.

Add top notch scary sound effects to all of that and Daylight is an absolute horror masterpiece.

It's important to note that I haven't yet completed the game yet. So this is just my early first impression of the game. And it's definitely on the right track.

reviewText:
Daylight. This game will ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing blow you away.

I never dreamed it will come to this, game world evolving real fast. Horror games on Unreal Engine 4!
While playing this horror game Daylight i saw great graphics, gameplay and excellent story.
You playing as a middle aged woman, who wake up in the haunted asylum. You need to find a way out, avoiding ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing ghosts and trying to find flares, they are really helpful. You will travel from asylum to prison and other locations including house, which will collapse in the end, but you will manage to escape before ghost got you, then end titles roll up.
I found this game very big and original, you can explore big areas and dark rooms. With new map system, your every playthrough will be unique, random generated rooms/areas. You can replay and enjoy this game for eternity!
Be careful, ghost can ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you up real quick, so just run pass them or hide somewhere. Its pretty scary i admire how ghost looks and behave, you could swear they look the same, but its not true. You getting slowly paranoid :D
Such an underrated horror game, but people want to play ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• like Witcher and Counter-strike these days :C

10/10

We need Daylight 2! Please!

reviewText: You awake in a building and you don't know where or why you are there. As your proceed you start to find about where you are, what happened there and why you are there. The gameplay is rather simple. You slowly explore areas and use glowsticks which help reveal items of interest around you (which is usefull as every playthrough is randomly generated), flares which 'burn' 'monsters' and your phone which acts as a map and light source. The game provides for a tense and creepy experience, although those looking for jump scares will be left dissapointed as the game has little in the way of such moments which I myself did not miss at all.\n\nThe largest potential issues I fell many may have is the games length, lack of inovation in terms of the horror and how easy it can become to get temporarioly lost largely as a result of its randamoly generated levels (note the levels are randomly generated, the objectives are not). Personally I like it when I get lost in a game especially when I am given the tools to not be lost (eg: thge map). Likewise it took myself three hours to finish though many have reported finishing the game in under an hour though replayability thanks to the levels always bieng different will be higher then in most similar games. Daylight however doesn't bring anything new to the horror game genre and whilst enjoyable will leave those expeccting new and/or unique mechanics dissapointed.

reviewText:
I really like this game, and the graphics and sound design are pretty good for a budget game; the environments are especially creepy and the use of glow sticks and flares is fun too.  This game‚Äôs main downside is that it suffered an increasingly popular gameplay mechanic that indie developers (mostly) utilize in budget ($15-$20 on Steam) horror games ‚Äì that of the random and/or pointless ‚Äòfetch‚Äô quest.  In Daylight‚Äôs case this takes the form of finding scraps of paper with a glowing sigil on them.

Once you find enough, some key-like item can then be collected from a magically-bound room that you in turn must use on a magically barred room/passage to proceed on to the next location, etc. Of course you have to backtrack to find said ‚Äòbarred‚Äô room/passage which can be a real pain in the a$$ considering that you can‚Äôt use a flare at that point to ward off the witches (the ghosts that appear in the game) and the map on the phone your character continually holds out (light is always on at least) in her right hand isn‚Äôt very helpful.  One other factor some will have an issue with is length - Daylight will only take most peeps on Steam about 1.5 ‚Äì 2 hrs to complete.

Granted, that is a pretty short length for a game, but when considering that the basis of this game is the proverbial ‚Äòfetch‚Äô quest, that doesn‚Äôt seem so bad in retrospect (seriously, would anyone want to endure a game that is 10+ hrs, or perhaps far longer, when that was the sole basis of said game? I think not!). There are trading cards, achievements and controller support as well, so that makes playing more enjoying and the achievements at least add some replay value if that‚Äôs your thing.

Not a bad game to finish on per se (the developers closed up shop after 20+ yrs recently so hopefully you won‚Äôt suffer a bug that prevents you from playing this game properly, if at all, as you just may be SOL at that point) and with the drop from $15 to $10 it definitely wouldn‚Äôt hurt to look into grabbing a copy for yourself.

reviewText:
Cool!

Runs fine on my specs.
Intel i5 3570k
Radeon 7870 2GB

Graphicwise I see some pretty lowres textures almost everywhere. Lighting is impressive though. It's a tad disappointing since this is the first game I've got running the Unreal 4 engine. I suppose I expected more. I don't think this game brings more eyecandy than Outlast, but if you're like me and couldn't enjoy Outlast because of the constant breathing sound then this will be awesome.
The sounds in this game is stellar.

Anyway, the pricepoint isn't farfetched at all and the game is kind of cool, I like it.

reviewText:
There was just so much potential in this game. I really could have liked it, if it hadn‚Äôt been for the severe graphics flaws. Daylight has wasted enough of my time, so I won‚Äôt bother going into the things you might like about the game, which for me, is a big deal as I try to keep an open mind and look for the positives in every game.

Daylight‚Äôs most severe issue is its heavy requirements to even play. You‚Äôve got a system check to make sure your computer can even handle loading the game much less play it in a comfortable fashion. Now, before I get hate-spam, yes, my computer got all passes on this checklist and all of my drivers are up to date. Still, playing this game with EVERY SINGLE SETTING AS LOW AS IT CAN POSSIBLY GO was almost impossible. I say almost because I have, in fact, beaten it multiple times, but it was a miserable experience and not worth the stress just to get the achievements. Even with the settings as low as possible, the game was choppy, the screen froze, I fell through the world twice in the forest, I had the game completely crash and close without warning, and on at least one occasion I had to reboot my computer to get out of the lock-up. I realized these problems, specifically the screen freezing, happened every single time I tried to use a flare. I would light the flare, and immediately it would freeze. I could hear the flare hissing away, I could even hear myself scream and hear the dying-notice pop up, but I would still be looking at a screen of hand half-raised with newly lit flare, and be unable to move. I ran four playthroughs of this game, and each time I spent the ENTIRE game staring at the floor and relying on the mini-map to move.

Another graphics issue is that at the end there are several cut-scenes, and I had no idea what these were supposed to be. It turns out, that is because my screen was ONLY showing a zoomed-in top-left hand corner of the whole picture before fading to blinding white and ending. I still have no idea what the real ending is supposed to look like. And I never will.

That being said, whether it‚Äôs a graphics issue or an AI issue, multiple times I would have a lit flare up and a witch would come out and kill me, and be completely unaffected by the flare (which is supposed to burn them away and defend you). This happened like clockwork in the prison level hard mode every single time I reached 6/8 remnants and attempted to look for numbers 7 & 8, six times in a row before I finally lucked out. That was the last of my runs. I have not gathered all the achievements on this game. For those that know me, this screams as to the quality of this game as I am an achievement addict and a masochist and will continue to play a game long after I‚Äôve lost interest in it JUST to complete the achievements.

All in all, I do not recommend Daylight. For the price they charge, four short chapters worth of content, and all the graphics nightmares of a rushed EA title, I‚Äôd recommend ordering some delivery and catching up on your favorite tv shows instead. You will have a much better time.

reviewText: First, let me start off by saying this is my first survival horror game, so this review is meant more as a supplement to other more seasoned reviews as opposed to a standalone. Also my playtime on record was mostly sitting time". I've spent maybe about 2-3 hours playing the game
date: and I'm maybe half way through. Most people say they beat it in 2 hours or less
recommended:
but I try to take my time on games and find everything.

I enjoy the genre of the game and am somewhat glad I got to expirience it because it opened me up to the genre. However it seems my first game in the genre was extremely lackluster compared to others which comes at a relief because this game is mediocre at best. I'm fortunate in the fact that I got this game for free with my graphics card I purchased.

The sound is the best quality of the game
hoursPlayed: with random noises in the background you would expect from these games
voteText: screams
votesHelpful: whatever that sound is the witches make as they chase you
votesTotal: etc. The music is good and adds suspense
votesFunny: I enjoy the little piano title song. Everything else in this game is below expectations. I'm most disapointed in the graphics. I expected better from the new unreal engine
commentsCount: however it looks like something that would have come out a few years ago. One reviewer described it as "looking like a student project" which is exactly what I thought as I walked through the randomly generated mazes.\n\nYou play as a girl named Sarah in which you really know nothing about
column16: and so far in my playthrough no character development has been attempted. Using a cellphone as a map/flashlight to light your way around the mazes of a hospital
column17: sewer
column18: prison
column19: and forest you search for remnants in the form of notes to peopel at the aforementioned areas that try to add some backstory to the areas you wander. Another reviewer described the narrative as "fan fiction grade" which I couldn't agree more. In the last one I found there was even a word missing which really urked me. After you find all the remnants in an area you can then find the key to use on a "magical door"
column20: as another reviewer described it
column21: to access the next area. While searching for said remnants and the key "witches" will appear around corners or behind you with a shrieking noise and then give chase unless you utilize a flare. They were kind of fun at first
column22: but now they are appearing too often and it has just become an annoyance. I had to take a break from the game because everytime I'd walk into a certain room a witch would appear and chase me out making me lose the progress I had made in the maze. Everytime I tried to get back to the room another witch would appear either in the room or in the hallway as I was making my way back to the room and chase me again. It happened at least five times in a row
column23: and I became very aggravated. Sarah walks at a pretty slow pace which requires some patience. I go through the game running pretty much everywhere I go. However
column24: while running the game tries to imitate some of the newer horror movies which are made as if they're home videos in the sense that the camera moves around a lot while the person filming moves. I.E. The Blair Witch Project. Lastly
column25: the game utilizes an autosave function with no way to manually save. There's no quitting whenever you want
column26: so hopefully you don't get too frightened or aggravated in between saves.\n\nAt the end of the day I would give this game a 5/10 and I can not recommend anyone pay $15 for it. As stated before I got it for free. At most I would pay $5 for this game. If you're looking for a new survival horror game
column27: have played all the other big titles
column28: and this game is on sale go ahead and give it a try. The game is scary but as most others have said there are better games in the genre.\n\nMy quotes throughout the review were from reviewer "[AReV]BavarianGod". You can find his review on this page

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cbw_BL80v3Q
At first I felt apprehensive playing Daylight, feeling it did a pretty good job of building up an oppressive atmosphere; however so little happens (and what does  is incredibly predictable), that my mood quickly changed to frustrated, and soon after; boredom. For example the random closing of doors had me spooked at first, wondering what I was going to see when I opened it... Nothing ever appeared. Things get knocked over or gently pushed across the floor, but they're completely unconnected actions; it's not to lure you in a particular direction or deter you, it‚Äôs just a random event that the developers thought would be spooky. Any fear I experienced came from my own expectations of what a horror game would involve.

The game boasts procedural content; however on the two occasions that I died (once because a ghost spawned right next to me, the other because I fell into water and couldn‚Äôt find a way out, exciting ways to go) I didn‚Äôt see much to support this. The layout of the area seemed to stay exactly the same, only the letters that you‚Äôre tasked with finding seemed to move. If there is more to it I certainly didn‚Äôt see it, and if you‚Äôre going to claim that each playthrough is going to be different, the game either needs to be good enough to warrant that second time or offer some incentive to. The game fulfils neither of those. The rooms and corridors are generally devoid of content and all look practically the same for a given level, to the extent where it feels like there are two sets of corridors and two room types. Procedural content is pointless if you only experience it once.

There's a few different areas to experience, with you being blocked off from the previous one each time you progress, so while there are no loading screens after the initial one, these serve as obvious barriers to save them having to keep too much geometry in memory. That may sound like trying to delve too much under the hood, but the knock on effect of the game play is that the game areas feel incredibly small, and not confined in the ‚Äúgood‚Äù claustrophobic way you'd want from a horror game.

Glowsticks are provided that highlight objects you can interact with when used; however not only is it not really necessary, it‚Äôs usually pretty obvious what you can click on, but it bathes the world in a garish shade of green. The only weapon you have against the shadows is a flare (no idea why), but it takes so long for the lighting animation to finish that if they‚Äôre close you may as well just run. Also, as per the silent hill radio, if a shadow is nearby the phone screen flickers, meaning; the moment you notice that, light a flare and spin around, since all shadows are killed instantly by it there is no danger at all in the game. The game provides a ‚Äúthreat‚Äù meter on screen, which gradually fills up as you find remnants, which I assume is supposed to be tied to shadow spawn frequency, however I've had shadows constantly spawning every few seconds with only a sliver of the threat meter filled in.

As such the game becomes a tedious chore of looking around the current environment for letters that are marked with a red seal, though the game doesn‚Äôt provide any context as to why these letters are littered around. Finding all the ones in the level spawns a sigil in the maze room, no indication as to why there are maze rooms in each level, which you then take to some aura‚Ä¶ thing, which blocks the exit to open up the next level. Again, no explanation as to what the mysterious power that blocks your way is.

Something that really brought me out of the experience was Sarah's insistence on calling out is someone there?" and the like
date: while I'm trying everything in my power to remain inconspicuous. While I understand it sells that Sarah is her own character and is affected by the situation
recommended: everytime I'd assume it was provoked by something and start spinning round trying to work out what it was
hoursPlayed: unfortunately there never seemed to be any specific trigger
voteText: which got really tiresome after the first few times. The other use of audio isn‚Äôt particularly noteworthy
helpfulPercent: you‚Äôll hear the assortment of effects you‚Äôd expect from a horror game
votesHelpful: but they never appeared to be tied to anything in game.\n\nIt took around two hours to finish the game
votesFunny: considering how little fun it is to play
commentsCount: may be some small solace
column16: but even at the reduced preorder price I paid
column17: I felt ripped off. Regardless of how long it took to beat though
column18: the gameplay is essentially 15 minutes long; once you've been through the first environment you‚Äôve essentially experienced all you‚Äôre going to with the game. The ‚Äúpuzzles‚Äù (if you get stumped moving a box into position or finding a switch to flip you can remove the quotes) are completely unnecessary and offer nothing to distract you from the tedium at hand.\n\nThe story itself is competent enough
column19: and put into a more tailored experience where the environments you go through actually mean something rather than being a conduit for letters
column20: it‚Äôd be fine. It really is a shame that the gimmick of the game is what ultimately fails it. I‚Äôm not going to say the game is absent of horror
column21: I‚Äôve been to plenty of movies where the rest of the audience has been in shock and disbelief at something I‚Äôve shrugged at
column23: Daylight was one of the mildest horror experiences I‚Äôve had in a long time."

reviewText: This is not worth you time, Very dissapointed, Atmosphere is nice and suspenceful at first, but once you see the 'Ghost' and learn that popping a flare is all it takes, the suspence goes immediately as she is not a threat to worry about and you can just dash right passed her with sprint. The game is so repetitive that it feels that you are doing the same part again, you go to one part of the hospital to the other collecting pages (Yes slender...) and then you escape that part and then do it all over again. Different parts of the map is copied and pasted leaving you very confused if you have just gone in a circle or not (The cut and paste job is so bad that the same room that you have just been in will be right next door). If you like Slender and the whole collect page, you will probably like this, but bare in mind, are you willing to pay for the same game concept as slender when you can get that for free?

reviewText:
i7 4770k processor
geforce gtx 650 ti boost card
16 gigs memory

My PC surpasses all reqs, and I only get ~22 fps on lowest settings. LOWEST SETTINGS.

On top of that, the game seems average at best. Everything looks off, the textures are muddy and low res, the environments are repetitive (IE random only in pathways), and the UI looks like it was thrown together in a week. Additionally, the game does nothing original. The gameplay mechanics are ripped off from Slender and Amnesia, among others.

The only good thing I noticed was the voice acting.

I'm going to play through it since I paid for it. I hope a few patches can fix these issues, because I had high hopes for this one.

reviewText:
Having just finished Daylight a couple minutes ago, it's still fresh in my mind. I beat it in one sitting in the span of about 80-ish minutes. I can't exactly say it was what I expected, but I don't exactly know what I expected.

First off, the game is quiet repetitive. Each area of the game requires you to collect about six Remnants" which if you've played Slender you can just call "Pages" Once you've gotten all of the Remnants you then must go find a "Sigil" which is a haunted item that unlocks the next area. Each area begins with a small transition stage where a lot of story related notes are. This formula persists throughout the entire game and can get dull after a while.

The game's backstory is told mostly by notes and the Remnants you collect around the level

reviewText:
I picked this game up for free with Nvidia's promotional offer with a GTX 780. I'm going to keep this short and simple.
The game starts off somewhat slow, but soon enough you are thrown into what the game is all about... suspense. Unfortunately, it doesn't last long. After about a half hour of gameplay, I'd seen everything the game had to offer... which is not much, I completed my first playthrough in two hours. None of the achievements appear to be working correctly for this game, as the ones I unlocked all popped up, but only one of them appears to have saved.

It was a great, if not short, timewaster, however it's not worth it's $15 pricetag. The way I figure it is, for two hours, it's more or less the cost of a movie, the often-compared to entertainment alternative to gaming. Time dependent, it lasts about as long as some movies, too. However, as stated above, after a half hour, I had seen everything the game had to offer, which, effectively aakes a half-decent movie a better buy.
The climax and conclusion of the last act" of the game

reviewText:
I'll just put the bottom line good and bad out there from what i've seen so far.

As always with these types of games it is best experienced with headphones in the dark.

The good.

Dark creepy atmosphere that is easy to get drawn into.

Excellent lighting effects.

Jump scares abound.

Easy to learn and use controls that remind you of amnesia.

Interesting story that is told through random flashbacks newspaper articles and some weird old dude talking over the phone.

Ghosts and shadows will definately make you jump out of your skin.

Pretty good quality graphics.

Reasonably priced game at 15$ Though I was smart and preordered. Try to get it for less than 10$ if you can.

The bad.

Persistant choppy lag that didn't go away even after I lowered the graphics setting to damn near mid 2000s era quality. This hindered me greatly and caused me no end of doom and frustration, Others are having the same issues as well I may add, this problem MUST be fixed as it is causing some poor souls' games to crash in bad cases.

Recycled enviroments that while randomly generated just don't fit together properly. One second I was in an insane asylum then a morgue then a prison cell block then back to an asylum. They could fix this by having certain areas only spawn around other areas that match them, Then we wouldn't have the confusing unrealistic layouts and everything would flow together seamlessly and make this feel like a true full on retail game.

Jump scares abound. Hey, This crap has been done to death if you like it more power to you but most people are tired of this recycled predictable scare tactic. Penumbra 1-2&3
hoursPlayed: and a whole slew of other games not to mention a few more that are STILL being developed all have already done it." (PS buy penumbra and amnesia if you haven't already. Totally worth it.) and while the ambiance IS creepy the jumpscare to ambiance ratio is a bit uneven leading to you just being annoyed by damn ghosts trying to kill you constantly.\n\nShadows that chase you endlessly. It is KINDA difficult to get ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• done and find all the clues you need to get through the game when the same freaking ghost appears every single time your freaking flare goes out causing you to lose health or die almost instantly. It makes exploring and finding what you MUST have to progress through the game nearly impossible and makes you not want to play it again. This must be fixed as well
voteText: I actually had to quit my game because I couldn't advance.\n\nRepetitive linear gameplay dispite the randomly generated maps. Do NOT let their talk of randomly generated maps fool you into think that this game will constantly be a new adventure
helpfulPercent:
You will STILL be hunting for the SAME objects in the SAME areas and the only thing that will be different is the layout. Nothing else changes and you still have to find 6 objects to make an object appear that allows you to proceed to the next area where you do the same exact thing. It is the very definition of Tedious.

IN CONCLUSION.

The game would function PERFECTLY if it were not for the lag as that was the only technical issue I personally have had and it seems to be the big issue with the game itself as many others have the same problem. While pretty to look at the quality of the graphics don't mean anything if the game is so full of lag that everything is constantly fading in and out of focus or glitching out! The game flow is obstructed by random out of place enviroments that just don't fit in which makes the game feel unrealistic which can make it hard to put yourself into the game if you are a fan of attention to detail. There are too many jump scares and not enough buildup to get to those scares which makes most of them in turn
votesHelpful: cheap
votesFunny: and predictable.\n\nThe game at it's core is tedious at best and a never ending array of poorly placed areas won't change that and if the developers thought it would distract people from their lazy game design they are dead wrong. As you play this game you will notice that it is nothing more than a mere knockoff of other better indie games

hard to put into words how diserpointed i was with this game. One thing i will say is dont buy it!!
firstly its only 2 to 3 hours long making it the shortest game iv ever played in my life!

There were a few good points to be fair. The game is really scairy and made me jump alot.
The game looks and sounds great too. There are lots of random sounds, screams,footsteps,bangs and bumps keeping you thinking is that something thats going to jump out and slice my face off or am i safe.

1 out of 10 at best.

The SCORE: I give this game a 6.5/10 Dull but could be better

More about the game: The plot is centered around a woman named Sarah who regains consciousness in an abandoned hospital with no memory of how she got there. A mysterious voice tells her to find the secrets of the hospital. With a cell phone, which is her map, she must explore the haunted hospital and its criminal past in order to escape. As she explores the hospital and the adjacent prison, Sarah begins to learn of the hospital's past, where twelve witches were executed and buried on the hospital grounds, with a thirteenth witch escaping death due to her turning in the other twelve witches. Sarah also discovers that she is a descendant of the thirteenth witch, and that the angry spirits of the twelve slain witches seek vengeance on her. However, it is unclear whether Sarah manages to escape the hospital or not find out yourself.

the player does not have access to weapons; the only tools available are glow sticks, flares, and a cell phone. The game's environment and layout are randomly generated for each gameplay, resulting in the very first maze game to use Unreal Engine 4. In addition, the enemies and other antagonists are procedurally spawned.

The player's goal in each level is to search for notes and logs from the hospital's past, referred to as remnants"
date: by looking for markings using glow sticks. Discovering remnants can cause a marking on her arm
recommended: which attracts the dangerous "shadow people". The player can either make them disappear by using flares or lose them by running away. Once all remnants in a level have been collected
hoursPlayed: the player is able to acquire a "sigil"
voteText: an item of significance to the hospital's past
helpfulPercent: such as a teddy bear and a Bible. Bringing the sigil to "the Seal of Shadows" will unlock the next part of the building
votesHelpful: allowing the player to advance further into the hospital and
votesFunny: to freedom.\n\nDaylight is a survival horror video game. It was released for the PlayStation 4 and Microsoft Windows on April 29
commentsCount: 2014. It was developed by Zombie Studios
column16: and is the first game to be powered by Unreal Engine 4."

reviewText: Not too short and not too long, this little title will make you jump more than a few times and look around frantically in the dark, with only your phone and a glowstick as your sources of light. Driven by an often vague and mysterious plot (which is uncovered both by cryptic messages on your phone and collecting snippets and photographs scattered around the levels) the game will certainly keep you playing it at least a few times over, if just to try and collect all of the collectibles and encounter other events, scares and level layouts.

reviewText: Do you enjoy collecting nonsensical story notes? Do you relish completely worthless characters babbling idiocy at you? Do you crave wandering bland environments in which inanimate objects move predictably to scare you? Do you wish not-really-scary monsters would pull the same tried and true disappearing acts over and over again? Well, friend, you're in luck! Buy this now and enjoy!\n\nTo its credit, the audio was fairly well done, but I'm really struggling to come up with anything else to say about this game that is positive. It looks pretty awful, has extremely repetitive gameplay, contains obnoxious and out of place character dialog, and is horribly predictable. The Slender formula was already showing its age, but this game drives it off the cliff. It's time to move on, folks. There are far better crafted horror games than this available on Steam. I recommend any of them over this.

reviewText:
i7 4770k processor
geforce gtx 650 ti boost card
16 gigs memory

My PC surpasses all reqs, and I only get ~22 fps on lowest settings. LOWEST SETTINGS.

On top of that, the game seems average at best. Everything looks off, the textures are muddy and low res, the environments are repetitive (IE random only in pathways), and the UI looks like it was thrown together in a week. Additionally, the game does nothing original. The gameplay mechanics are ripped off from Slender and Amnesia, among others.

The only good thing I noticed was the voice acting.

I'm going to play through it since I paid for it. I hope a few patches can fix these issues, because I had high hopes for this one.

reviewText:
Nothing new to see here...

This game draws on many of the already established tropes of the horror games of recent years. Whilst the procedurely generated structure is interesting, the game does not seem to provide any changes on subsequent playthroughs, and is not interesting enough to play more than once. Completion time for me was about 2 hrs.

Alone with no weapon" was much better accomplished by the PS2 Project Zero games (AKA Fatal Frame)
"Jump scares" have been rather done-to-death
"Mysterious notes" appear in pretty much all games - although not as an objective
"Asylum" - so many games seem to be set in an asylum!

Not recommened at full price - but may be worth getting when it comes down to sub ¬£5"

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game?
Yes.

Do I like every aspect of it?
No.

It has an interesting story, with overused, redudent story telling.

Overall, I'd give it a 7.5/10


This is very Outlast in nature, while not exactly following up to the latter.  You start off in a mental institution, and as the story progresses, I think some old crazy dude talking to me on my phone wants me to explore my past?  I don't really remember.  The monologues from the characters aren't exactly memorable, however the puzzle/horror style of the game, at least to me, is pretty memorable.  This game heavily relies on jump scares, most of which do have some shock value.

Pros
Puzzle/horror/atmospheric works
Fun story
Mostly memorable game
Runs smoothly on higher (not highest) quality graphics.

Cons
Very repatitive
(AS IN, FIND YOUR WAY THROUGH THIS MAZE LEVEL TO GET TO THE NEXT!)
Some jump scares fall short
Sometimes the guy on the phone really breaks you out of the atmosphere of the game

BONUS
HOW HAS MY PHONE NOT RUN OUT OF BATTERY YET?  SERIOUSLY WHAT KIND OF BATTERY DOES THIS THING HAVE, BECUASE MY IPHONE 5 COULD REALLY USE IT!

reviewText: This game is half-baked and lands very short of it's ambitions. It leaves a somwehat interesting aftertaste, but the playing itself is rather boring. It feels like a very early alpha of some indie game.\nGenerated levels is an idea that sounds cool, but in the actual game those generated mazes look dull, repetitive and awfully cluttered. If the devs were braver and added more glitchiness and weirness (think Memory of Broken Dimension) maybe it woul've been more interesting. But they chose to just throw a heap of horror game cliches in a weak attempt to follow Outlast footsteps. Unsuccessfully. Gotta be bolder with this type of game.

reviewText:
hard to put into words how diserpointed i was with this game. One thing i will say is dont buy it!!
firstly its only 2 to 3 hours long making it the shortest game iv ever played in my life!
The storey isnt much good ether and leaves alot of things unexplained.
There were a few good points to be fair. The game is really scairy and made me jump alot.
The game looks and sounds great too. There are lots of random sounds, screams,footsteps,bangs and bumps keeping you thinking is that something thats going to jump out and slice my face off or am i safe.
The downside though is most of the game looks the same all the time. Every hall every door every room there all the same just repeated over and over again and it just starts to feel lazy and a little dull.
The first hour or so of the game leaves you not really knowing if you have gone anywere at all as it still looks the same as when you started out.
This game could have been great but its falls so short of even been average. The people that made this really didnt try to do anything with it at all! other than test out the new unreal 4 engine.
1 out of 10 at best.
