reviewText:
I have very mixed feelings about this particular game. I'm recommending it, but only during a Steam sale.

On the one hand, there were segments where I genuinely felt scared as I was traversing the level. As you get further through the game, the enemies become more plentiful and harder to fend off with your flares. It felt like I got to a point where a new ghost would spawn every 10 feet and I'd have to activate my last flare to kill it or i'd just have to run away. This always kept me on edge and hoping i'd get another flare soon.

On the negative side of things, I don't think this game does Unreal Engine 4 justice. Everything from the textures to some of the lighting just looks very mediocre. Instead of the in-game objects looking sharp and clear on max settings, they seem to just look fuzzy. I don't know if they just directly ported the PS4 version of the game with minimal changes or what.

The other thing is the player character's commentary about the area around you. Alot of it seemed out of place and even annoying at times. I understood the context that Sarah, protagonist, is scared of everything around her, but asking Is somebody there?" when it's obvious that no one is broke the immersion for me. That said
recommended: I felt her commentary was much more appropriate.\n\nWatch some gameplay on youtube before you decide to buy. Otherwise
hoursPlayed: avoid."

reviewText: I'm trying to get as many of the current horror games coming out as I can get, but...  After playing this for even less than an hour, I was kind of bored.  I had a couple scares, but they were two scares in almost one moment.  For the most part you just wander around, picking up papers that give a little bit of information on what has gone on in the hospital and then proceed by finding a special object and opening some portal to the next area.  Meanwhile you are followed and watched by some ghost.  You hear screams, footsteps that may be your own, weird sounds, and even a ghost once in a while.  The ghosts aren't even that scary most of the time.  I don't scare easy playing these like the ones on YouTube, but I think some of that is an act anyway, most reactions aren't, but again, I don't react to the scares as much as many do.\n\nThis game is tedious, repetative, hardly scary, same old ghost stories you always hear, and nothing seems to kill you.  I played it for an hour and nothing killed me...Not even close!  I never came close to dying even once during the first two parts of it.  A BIG PASS!

reviewText:
Pros
Voice acting is great!
Sound design is amazing!
Story is great!
Some rather disturbing moments.
Walking Simulator 2014

Cons
Visuals are pretty bland, poor use of Unreal4 they could have done SOOO much more to this game.
Repetitive dialouge ( Ermahgerd whos dar? Ermahger whos dar? - Sarah)
Repetitive level models ( doors, rooms, hallways all look the bloody same!!! )
Uninspired enemy ( Slenderman comes into mind but alot less frightening and easily avoidable just ignore the old bat.)
Repetitive and uninspired gameplay mechanics.

5/10

Could have done so much more with this game. I'm going to make up for it and get the new OutLast DLC a proper horror game. Daylight was a let down and felt more like a benchmark.

reviewText:
Having just finished Daylight a couple minutes ago, it's still fresh in my mind. I beat it in one sitting in the span of about 80-ish minutes. I can't exactly say it was what I expected, but I don't exactly know what I expected.

First off, the game is quiet repetitive. Each area of the game requires you to collect about six Remnants" which if you've played Slender you can just call "Pages" Once you've gotten all of the Remnants you then must go find a "Sigil" which is a haunted item that unlocks the next area. Each area begins with a small transition stage where a lot of story related notes are. This formula persists throughout the entire game and can get dull after a while.

The game's backstory is told mostly by notes and the Remnants you collect around the level
date: it isn't too much. Mainly just exposition about the hospital
hoursPlayed: and how it was shut down. While the main storyline in the game is almost invisible. The game doesn't tell you why you're there and the only reason I know why is from a developer interview with TotalBiscuit where it was mentioned. But other than that you pretty much walk through the hospital and listen to the voices of two people. Yourself
voteText: who's only comments usually consists of "Is someone in there?" Or "Oh god! Make it stop!"
votesHelpful: who talks to the main character (Sarah) throughout her quest. I don't believe the game ever tells you who he is or how the hell he's talking to you in the first place. I'm assuming it's through the phone but I'm not sure. The ending is... Okay. Don't expect it to wow you in any way and expect to get a little whiplash from it's sudden climax. It felt like they were rushing to clear things up
votesFunny: and end the game right then and there.\n\nThe horror aspect isn't anything special
commentsCount: but it's well done. I jumped out of my seat quite a few times upon encountering the ghost. Named "Shadows" by the game. You're only way to fight them off are using the flares

Using a glowstick reveals key items such as containers that might contain items and key items. (Mainly containers though.) As well as providing a decent amount of light. The ghosts are scary enough

Where as the story was a little confusing, the gameplay was smooth and controls are very simple. 1 for glowsticks, 2 for flares, and M for map, thats just about all you need to know. the game didn't have much jumpscares for me, mainly because i was on the easy difficulty, so i would recommend being on medium or hard diffuculty for a more Challenging" more "Frightening" expirence. it is a little overpriced for a short game

reviewText:
I picked this game up for free with Nvidia's promotional offer with a GTX 780. I'm going to keep this short and simple.
The game starts off somewhat slow, but soon enough you are thrown into what the game is all about... suspense. Unfortunately, it doesn't last long. After about a half hour of gameplay, I'd seen everything the game had to offer... which is not much, I completed my first playthrough in two hours. None of the achievements appear to be working correctly for this game, as the ones I unlocked all popped up, but only one of them appears to have saved.

It was a great, if not short, timewaster, however it's not worth it's $15 pricetag. The way I figure it is, for two hours, it's more or less the cost of a movie, the often-compared to entertainment alternative to gaming. Time dependent, it lasts about as long as some movies, too. However, as stated above, after a half hour, I had seen everything the game had to offer, which, effectively aakes a half-decent movie a better buy.
The climax and conclusion of the last act" of the game
date: seemigly suppossed to be the most suspenseful
recommended: ended up being the least suspenseful part of the game. I'll avoid spoilers here... but suffice to say
hoursPlayed: it was completed by just continually sprinting around. You'll understand how effective it is
voteText: should you endure through the game to get there yourself.\n\nWhile this game is procedurally generated
votesHelpful: the map changes... it offers very limited replayability. All the scripted jump scares happen in all the same places
votesTotal: and you come to expect them.\n\nOn the onset of my second playthrough
votesFunny: it also appears to be the same storyline."

reviewText:
Really resisting the urge to turn on all my lights right now. Daylight to me so far seems pretty solid. Definitely a game for horror fans and those who like figuring out mysteries. Controls seem stiff but its something you get used to (and by stiff I mean the speed which you turn, tried adjusting sensitiivity, didn't do anything for me.)

I've read a lot of negative stuff about this so far. That stuff doesn't work and such. I haven't seen any problems so far. Then again I didn't start playing til after a couple of updates.

The atmosphere is creepy. This will look very good on high end machines. The halls look a lot alike. So if getting lost annoys you prepare yourself because you're gonna be checking your phone often to find the right way. Again if liitle things like that annoy you prepare yourself. Then again its another thing you'll get used to.

Is this worth 14.99? Maybe. Should you buy it on sale? Yes. When I play more my opinion may change either way for this game.

reviewText:
I have very mixed feelings about this particular game. I'm recommending it, but only during a Steam sale.

On the one hand, there were segments where I genuinely felt scared as I was traversing the level. As you get further through the game, the enemies become more plentiful and harder to fend off with your flares. It felt like I got to a point where a new ghost would spawn every 10 feet and I'd have to activate my last flare to kill it or i'd just have to run away. This always kept me on edge and hoping i'd get another flare soon.

On the negative side of things, I don't think this game does Unreal Engine 4 justice. Everything from the textures to some of the lighting just looks very mediocre. Instead of the in-game objects looking sharp and clear on max settings, they seem to just look fuzzy. I don't know if they just directly ported the PS4 version of the game with minimal changes or what.

The other thing is the player character's commentary about the area around you. Alot of it seemed out of place and even annoying at times. I understood the context that Sarah, protagonist, is scared of everything around her, but asking Is somebody there?" when it's obvious that no one is broke the immersion for me. That said
recommended: I felt her commentary was much more appropriate.\n\nWatch some gameplay on youtube before you decide to buy. Otherwise
hoursPlayed: avoid."

reviewText: I'm trying to get as many of the current horror games coming out as I can get, but...  After playing this for even less than an hour, I was kind of bored.  I had a couple scares, but they were two scares in almost one moment.  For the most part you just wander around, picking up papers that give a little bit of information on what has gone on in the hospital and then proceed by finding a special object and opening some portal to the next area.  Meanwhile you are followed and watched by some ghost.  You hear screams, footsteps that may be your own, weird sounds, and even a ghost once in a while.  The ghosts aren't even that scary most of the time.  I don't scare easy playing these like the ones on YouTube, but I think some of that is an act anyway, most reactions aren't, but again, I don't react to the scares as much as many do.\n\nThis game is tedious, repetative, hardly scary, same old ghost stories you always hear, and nothing seems to kill you.  I played it for an hour and nothing killed me...Not even close!  I never came close to dying even once during the first two parts of it.  A BIG PASS!

reviewText:
This game is short. So is my review. You can easily beat it in one seat.

Daylight adds not too much to the horror/survival/run & hide genre. It is actually not obligatory run & hide, because you can repel your enemies with a flare, because a bright light fears these pesky shadow creations just like Mogwai fears Satan.

The remarkable things about Daylight are the following. It is the first game, built on top of the Unreal Engine 4. It is the most remarkable thing. The graphics however are not of any next-gen look. The physics too is not of any particular interest, so the Unreal Engine 4 is not really a big deal here.

Just like the other games of its keen, I mean Penumbra, Amnesia and Outlast, it introduces a new source of light ‚Äî the smartphone with unlimited battery life. It easily lightens up any dark in the game, but you are encouraged to use two different and somewhat scarce light sources (worth to mention, these borrowed from Penumbra series) ‚Äî green glowsticks and bright red flares. Unlike Penumbra's counterparts, these two are not last enough, but glowsticks highlights key items, unveiling an intricate ‚Äòmazy' lines on top of it, and flares fears Satan... em, sorry, Shadows. Shadows are a ghostly witches, which are the Sarah's sole enemies in the game and in the most parts of Daylight there is just one Shadow to be aware of.

The gameplay is conforming to the next pattern. At first you enter a randomly generated maze, often it is the hospital's corridors and ruined rooms. In it you should collect some quantity of so called remnants (basically notes, explaining the game's events, just like in Penumbra, Amnesia and Outlast). After this is done, you go to some weird illuminated room, where you collect some floating object, like teddy bear. It is a key to the illuminated door in the different part of the maze.

The whole ‚Äòmazing‚Äô part is not really amazing, but you may get shiver or two, because the Shadow have a tendency to spawn somewhere near you with a frightening sound. But, as was previously said, you should not necessary run away from the creep, just light up the flare and it will disappear for a while.

After the maze part here comes a narrative part, where you just proceed through the location, occasionally grabbing some not necessary to be collected remnants (these marked with a blue lights apart of necessary red). Then the maze part again. Repeat it four or five times and you will find yourself finished the game.

'This is all?‚Äô you may have ask yourself, starring to the final credit titles. Yes, it actually is, and there are even no hints to the possible sequel. That's it. That's Daylight.

Important question may come to your head, when you reading this review ‚Äî is Daylight any scary? Is it worth a time? The answer is yes, it is a somewhat scary. But not that scary, as Outlast, Amnesia and Penumbra. Because of flares. Flares adds a good amount of comfort to the overall feeling.

Will I recommend this game? I am a bit hesitant on this and if there is a kind of abstain button here on Steam reviews page, then I will press it. The game is a worthwhile and not at the same time. But as there is no such thing, let it be 'Yes, I recommend'.

reviewText: SHAKY CAM!!!!  Buyer beware that this game has intense shaky cam. Even when you stand still, the camera is bobbing up and down, left and right. There is no need for this. I feeling like I'm going to puke just staring at the screen for ten seconds. Shaky cam in this instance does not add immersion. In real life, when I stand still, my head does not bob up and down left and right.  This is a cheap gimmick that makes the game unplayable. REsident Evil remake for gamecube gave and still gives plenty of chills, and that game had fixed camera! Environments in RE were rendered in 2D. I cannot understand why the developers would think shaky cam adds to the horror" element and immersion. Even if I didn't get nauseous

reviewText:
I find this game to entertaining and an over all joy to play. The graphics are great and while the gameplay is short it is a must to play it 2-3 times atleast to truly get the most out of it.

There seem to be alot of issues with people being unable to play or getting crashes. I personally had some issues getting this game to run but as with 99.999% of the problems out there it was MY FAULT. After some quick tinkering I fixed my issues and havn't had a problem since.

A major plus for me is the lack of bugs in this game. The people who are having issues with bugs, glitches, and crashes it is a user problem and in no way the fault of the devs. If your system can't handle the game you shouldn't have purchased it.

Over all I would give this game a 9/10 with the only drawback is the length of the gameplay itself. Replay makes up for this but at the end you are left with a desire for more.

reviewText: This feels more like a scripting demonstration then an actual game. There's really no reason for the procedurally generated levels and the main themes present in the story feel more like they're trying to work with the mechanics, but instead of mixing well it just feels incredibly forced.  And as far as mechanics go there isn't much going on here. It cycles between finding items to trigger events, finding keys to locked doors,\n\nIf you're looking for that next-gen horror game that's going to push the boundaries of what FPS horror games are capable of, it's not going to be here. If you're even looking for something that's just alright or mediocre, it's not here either. I'd put this on the lowest tiers of horror like Slender.

reviewText: Do you enjoy collecting nonsensical story notes? Do you relish completely worthless characters babbling idiocy at you? Do you crave wandering bland environments in which inanimate objects move predictably to scare you? Do you wish not-really-scary monsters would pull the same tried and true disappearing acts over and over again? Well, friend, you're in luck! Buy this now and enjoy!\n\nTo its credit, the audio was fairly well done, but I'm really struggling to come up with anything else to say about this game that is positive. It looks pretty awful, has extremely repetitive gameplay, contains obnoxious and out of place character dialog, and is horribly predictable. The Slender formula was already showing its age, but this game drives it off the cliff. It's time to move on, folks. There are far better crafted horror games than this available on Steam. I recommend any of them over this.

reviewText: One word: YES. If you are a streamer, you need to play this game with your followers at least once. The Twitch integration is amazing - log in after you start streaming, and your viewers can enter commands to make things happen around you. These come in the form of apparitions, screams, footsteps, and many other things. I'd highly recommend it on that basis alone, but I am not sure it would be AS interesting if you were playing alone. The viewers really help the experience.

reviewText:
Make no mistake, this game will scare the bejeesus out of you, and if it doesn't, then mister - you're a better man than I.

But is that enough?

Because, basically, that's all you get. If you're a fan of the horror genre in general, be it movies, books or games then you'll probably be able to predict what happens next. This game unashamedly trots out all the horror tropes - almost by the book - for better or worse, and for veterans of the genre, this might make it seem a little tired.

But for some, the fact that it plays from the Horror Cliches 101 textbook can work in its favour. You will be deliciously on edge as you pass by that wheelchair, because you just know it's going to suddenly move its squeaky wheels in your direction. If I look through this window, is a ghastly face going to appear on the other side, looking back?

It's moments like these that make this game so intense and frightening at times, to say nothing of the supernatural denizens that reside in the asylum that you may or may not come face to face with.

But if you're expecting deep gameplay and open ended exploration you will be sorely disappointed. Although this game does what it promises - scares the crap out of you - there's nothing much else really to it. You wander around hunting for Remnants, in game lore items, while waiting for the next supernatural event to occur. And, well, that's pretty much all she wrote.

It becomes somewhat tedious after awhile trudging through the same recycled corridors. And let me tell you, there are a LOT of corridors. For a game that was hyped as much as it was for using the Unreal 4 engine, the graphics and textures look somewhat muddy and washed out, at least they did on my rig. They definitely have a previous-gen look about them. And this is baffling, considering the fairly hefty system requirements. Though the sound design is excellent, and perfectly complements what's going on onscreen.

For the price though, give it a shot if you're a fan of survival horror games or horror stuff in general - you'll enjoy it, at least for a while - for this game is best enjoyed in short chunks, rather than extended play sessions.

In summary, it's horror-by-the-numbers fare that will absolutely have you browning trou, but apart from the scares, there is little on offer here in the way of gameplay and with surprisingly meaty running requirements at odds with the ordinary graphics you'll want to be a survival horror fan to appreciate this. If you want something you can savour, and enjoy being scared then, for the price especially, you can't go wrong here.

A slightly above average 6 out of 10.

reviewText: yawn!  What a snoozefest. Procedurally generated boredom.  So cliche it's difficult to count the infinite ways it's derivative. I had high hopes, which have not even slightly been met. Game play mechanics just short of watching a dvd. Bits of story and plot which could have been lifted from Silent Hill, Resident Evil, Siren or any other true survival horror masterpiece. The environments are done well, and it's amazing that it's procedural, but it's a boring maze which utterly failed to capture my interest. If I'm a rat in your Spooky Procedurally Generated Maze, where's my cheese?  This game has ZERO FPS elements and ZERO RPG elements and ZERO RTS elements. What exactly is the point? Wandering around a haunted house so you can jump out and say BOO? I got this for FREE when i bought my GTX770. I wish I could get my time back, since I didn't waste any money. I Don't think anyone else should waste money on this either.

reviewText:
TL;DR pretty scary but there's really no point to playing this game.

It's pretty dang scary. But... kind of boring. Wander through a huge labyrinth of hallways that all look the same trying to find 6 little notes. I feel like there are WAY too many hallways though. I only need 6 notes and it's kind of a pain to look through 50 hallways just to find 6 little notes (not that there should be more notes). This game is basically Slender, but with a cookie cutter environment that has almost no landmarks. Yeah, you have a map, but all it does is show you where you've been. So it can help you find things you've already found but nothing else. It'd be nice if it showed you doors that you haven't opened in a hallway you've already visited.

The little scares are pretty stupid too. EHRMAGERD! A STACK OF BOXES FELL DOWN. SO SPOOKY!" Yeah. Decent voice acting. Protagonist gets really spooked over little scares apparently. *Bottles rattle and fall over* "AHHHHHH!"

Ultimately
recommended: but there's not really a point in playing this game. I constantly find myself just wandering around looking for one last note for 5-10 minutes (or until I run out of flares
hoursPlayed: evil-woman basically pops up every 10 seconds) thinking "whats the point?"\n\nAlso

reviewText: If I had to sum it up, I would say that it's a bad slender clone.\nNow for the long explanation. I got this game when I purchased my GTX 760, so I didn't pay actual money for this game, so if it sucked, then it wouldn't be the worst thing ever. First I must mention how barebones the option menu is. There is little to nothing to adjust there, and most of the things that you can adjust there arn't very well described at all. Now the graphics. This is a section which I don't entirely hate. I actually think that the visuals are really good, with some exelent lighting effects here and there, what I hate about them, is that even on my GTX 760, it chuggs from time to time. I think this might be due to some sort of autosave thing working like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, but it's really abnoxious. The sound design isn't that bad either, and is probably the game's best strength about it. Now the story. I didn't complete the game entirely because the beforementioned preformance issues were too much for me to handle, but from what I played of it, the story, while not bad, wasn't good either. Now the enemy, oh boy. The enemies in this game follow you around sorta like slenderman, exept without the teleporting ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t, so that's a plus I guess. But my big problem with them, is that you can just stash a bunch of flares, and run into the enemy when you rarely see them. And for the gameplay, you colect stuff and go to a certian area to escape, like slender :P\nThe only reason I'm not harsher on this game, is because I never spent actual money on it, and got it with my graphics card, but don't buy it, it's a turd among greater horror games.

reviewText: One word: YES. If you are a streamer, you need to play this game with your followers at least once. The Twitch integration is amazing - log in after you start streaming, and your viewers can enter commands to make things happen around you. These come in the form of apparitions, screams, footsteps, and many other things. I'd highly recommend it on that basis alone, but I am not sure it would be AS interesting if you were playing alone. The viewers really help the experience.

reviewText: If this game is supposed to showcase DX11 it fails.  It's a boring game and I've seen better graphics in none DX11 games!  While there are some initial scary moments you soon realize that there is no reason to be scared.  I'm glad I got this game for free with a download code included with the purchase of my GTX 780 Ti.  I installed it expecting the graphics to be jaw-dropping with DX11 and didn't get it.  I installed it with the anticipation that the game would probably suck...and it does.  This game" should be a free download on the Nvidia website.  2 out of 10 because it's a playable 'demo'."

reviewText: This game is an extreme disappointment.  Desipite using Unreal 4 to power it, it is a very generic, very empty, and very repetitive game.   The fact that you have to replay it several times just to get all the story info is a cheap play extending" tactic used by weak developers.  I'm not sure I want to finish this game once
date: let alone play it several more times.\n\nLevels are random for the most part and there appears to be no kind of algorithm that keeps one particular piece from being used to often.  There will be  times where you will see the same room in a section more than once
recommended: often more than three times.\n\nThere is no combat
hoursPlayed: but there is danger that ends your game.  This can be frustrationg because the supposed way to beat the typical danger is with a flare but it doesn't alwats work.  I don't understand why sometimes it works
voteText: other times it doesn't and there is no explanation as to why.  A flaw in the design or prerhaps a bug.\n\nDeath is completely irritating because you must start the current level completely from the beginning
helpfulPercent: meaning even if you're two steps from finishing the level and unlocking the next if you die then you must explore the level and collect everything AGAIN.  I am currently stuck early in the game because after collecting a key to unlock the next level I am confronted with the adversary and cannot avoid or defeat it in anyway.\n\nThere are only autosaves in this game
votesHelpful: and the game is only saved at the start of each new section
votesTotal: or level.  Another ignorant developer who thinks they know better than we do on how we want to play again so they forgo manual saves.  I am sick of the this
votesFunny: developers egos or laziness taking my NEED to be able to save the god damn game when I want to.  Auto saves are fine
commentsCount: but a game has to have manual saves as well.\n\nThe game looks and feels creepy with the typical decrepit asylum environment

column17: and random
column18: but limited
column19: dialogue form the protagonist or one other charater. Still

column21: there are very few things that aren't static
column22: and even most of the non-static things function rarely to provie jump scares.\n\nI have not come across any puzzles
column23: just the typical notes you find that tell a piece of the story.  Some backtracking is required as you must find both the key and the exit which are typically on opposite ends of the map
column24: and you cannot get the key until you've collected all the specific notes in the area.\n\nAll in all this is a very basic game.  Very basic gameplay

Unreal Engine 4 is awesome!"\n\nIf ther eis anything good to say about the game then it would be these:  the sound quality is well done

It doesn't do the Urnreal Engine any favors by being the "first" Unreal 4 game due to it's lack of and kind of visual treats."

reviewText:
This game came for free with my graphics card.  I played it through once because I had it, so why not.

The graphics are pretty unimpressive for being  UE4 and the lighting system isn't even that cool.  Glowsticks and flares just turn your screen red/green they aren't even that dynamic.

The game takes far less than 2 hours to beat, even if you are going slow.  You'll never want to play it again. Not being mean, just saying - there's no reason.   You'll quickly see what it means by procedural" and randomization and its like < half the game is random
date: and that portion is by far the most boring part.\n\nNo way I'd ever buy this game for ten bucks.  However
recommended: for like .99 cents or 1.99 maybe on sale
hoursPlayed: I might get it just for the two hour playthrough.  It's like renting a bad movie.  The notes were kinda cool
voteText: but pretty cliche and poorly written.  Everything about it was pretty weak

to make it short

dont buy fullprice! if you want a scare play outlast first!

little more detailed

the game is not bad, its just neither worth the price nor does it seem to run smooth. its unreal 4 but to be honest i didnt see that! sure there are these 2 special graphical effects but thats it. runs a lot worse than for example outlast, which looks AND plays better(unreal 3 afaik). worst is, that i cannot play beyond a certain point in the game, where it simply freezes. tried 5 times now. the game should be inmproved and fixed. randomized scares are ok, randomized levels are not. it can give you the creeps for sure, but the replayability is pretty low, and the levels dont feel convincable.

6/10 (if you can run it and finish)

reviewText:
Very short, nonsensical story and cheap scares (suddenly appearing with sound effect).

Gameplay is rather limited, which would be fine for interactive fiction but this attempts to have two kinds of light for different tasks: glowsticks to find clues and flares to fend off witches. This at most is silly gimmick instead of plausible gameplay-mechanic at won't keep you interested for long.

It is mostly useful as a tech-demo of UE4, story does not have much content and not much replayability.

Not worth it.

Based on what I've played, what I've seen, and on my friend's similar feelings on it, I do not recommend this game.

reviewText:
Have you ever hated a game?

Have you ever hated a game so much that you keep beating your head against it, like it's a brick wall and you're not going to stop until you get a concussion?

Daylight is that game for me. Zombie Studios is notorious for producing sub-par products - and Daylight is no exception to that rule: the challenges that it present are laughable at best (in the case of the intended challenge of the witches, which can be avoided by staring at the floor like a shoegaze guitarist and - well, shoe gazing); and absurd at worst (in the case of achievement hunting, which is a chore). Like the gameplay, the story is clunky and poorly delivered. There is a cyclical system to witchery in this world, that begins with the death of witches, and follows a twelve-step program to awaken the power within the witches' descendent.

The one thing that's charming about the game is the narrator - a spooky doctor who's doing his very best to monologue like Anthony Hopkin's Lecter. His overacting is a source of unexpected levity in an otherwise tedious experience.

That aside, don't make the same mistake I did. I'm going to finish the long quest of achievement hunting and then uninstall for good.
